core_information.study_title: Cognitive training via a mobile application to reduce some forms of body dissatisfaction in young females at high-risk for body image disorders: A randomized controlled trial
core_information.affiliations: University of Padova (Italy), Reichman University (Israel)

study_details.study_type: Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) with crossover design
study_details.participant_demographics: Young Italian women aged 20-30 years (Mean age = 22.82, SD = 2.11)
study_details.duration: 16 days intervention with assessments at baseline (T0), 16 days (T1), and 32 days (T2)
study_details.target_population: Young females at high-risk for Body Image Disorders (BIDs)

study_content.summary: This RCT investigated the efficacy of the GGBI mobile app (from GGtude platform) in reducing body dissatisfaction, BDD/ED symptoms, and associated features in high-risk young females. Participants were randomized into immediate-use app (iApp, n=47) and delayed-use app (dApp, n=48) groups using a crossover design.
key_findings: Significant Group × Time interaction showing decrease in BDD symptoms and body dissatisfaction related to EDs in the immediate-use app group
34.74% of participants achieved reliable change on extreme body dissatisfaction/BDD symptoms
Effects were maintained at 2-week follow-up
Results were replicated in delayed-use group after crossover
More limited effects on ED symptoms (bulimia, drive for thinness) and associated features (perfectionism, social anxiety, self-esteem)

measurable_improvements.result: Significant reductions from baseline to post-intervention (p < .001)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Large effect sizes (ηp² = .13 to .50)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: 34.74% of participants showed reliable change

measurable_improvements.metric: Body Dissatisfaction related to EDs (EDI-3 BD subscale)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Medium-large effect sizes (ηp² = .08 to .28)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: 10.53% showed reliable change

measurable_improvements.result: Within-group reductions from baseline to follow-up (p = .02-.05)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Medium effect sizes (ηp² = .12 to .25)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: 10.53% showed reliable change

measurable_improvements.result: Within-group reductions with large effect sizes
measurable_improvements.effect_size: ηp² = .15 to .31
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: 13.68% showed reliable change

study_content.statistical_significance: Bonferroni corrected p-value = .006 applied to all measures

core_information.study_title: Cognitive Training via a Mobile Application to Reduce Obsessive-Compulsive-Related Distress and Cognitions During the COVID-19 Outbreaks: A Randomized Controlled Trial Using a Subclinical Cohort
core_information.affiliations: Baskent University, Hacettepe University, Ankara Haci Bayram Veli University (Turkey), Interdisciplinary Center of Herzliya (Israel)

study_details.study_type: Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) with crossover design
study_details.participant_demographics: Turkish community participants, iApp group (n=25, 19 females, Mean age=26.36, SD=11.18), dApp group (n=20, 12 females, Mean age=22.63, SD=6.62)
study_details.duration: 12 days intervention per group, assessments at T0, T1 (12 days), and T2 (24 days)
study_details.target_population: Community participants with subclinical OCD symptoms (scoring 2 SD above mean on OCI-R during COVID-19 pandemic)

study_content.summary: This RCT evaluated the effectiveness of GG OCD mobile app (GGtude platform) in reducing OCD symptoms and cognitions during the COVID-19 pandemic in a Turkish subclinical sample. The study used a crossover design with immediate-app use (iApp) and delayed-app use (dApp) groups, with participants completing 3 levels per day (approximately 3-4 minutes) for 12 consecutive days.
key_findings: Large effect-size reductions (Cohen's d ranging from .87 to 2.73) in OCD symptoms and maladaptive cognitions
Significant Group × Time interactions for OCI-R, OBQ-44, and IUS-12
iApp group showed significant reductions from T0 to T1 which were maintained at T2 follow-up
dApp group replicated results after crossover (T1 to T2)
No significant effects on DASS-21 subscales (depression, anxiety, stress)
Marginally significant effects on contamination cognitions (p = .08)
Overall dropout rate of 18% during app use

measurable_improvements.result: Significant reductions in iApp group from T0 to T1 (p < .001), maintained at T2. Replicated in dApp group T1 to T2 (p < .001)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Very large: Cohen's d = 1.74 to 2.73; ηp² = .43 to .65
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Not specified per measure

measurable_improvements.result: Significant reductions in iApp group T0 to T1 (p < .001), maintained at T2. Replicated in dApp group T1 to T2 (p < .001)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Large: Cohen's d = .87 to 2.04; ηp² = .44 to .51
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Not specified per measure

measurable_improvements.result: Significant reductions in iApp group T0 to T1 (p < .001), maintained at T2. Replicated in dApp group (p < .01)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Large: Cohen's d = 1.12 to 2.04; ηp² = .24 to .51
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Not specified per measure

measurable_improvements.result: Marginally significant Time × Group interaction (p = .08). Significant within-group reductions from T0 to T2
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Medium to large: Cohen's d = .87 to .91; ηp² = .16 to .17
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Not specified per measure

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Not significant
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Not applicable

study_content.statistical_significance: Multiple imputation used for missing data (MICE method). Bonferroni correction applied for multiple comparisons.

core_information.study_title: Brief cognitive-behavioral training for tinnitus relief using a mobile application: A pilot open trial
core_information.affiliations: Tel-Aviv Sourasky Medical Center, Tel Aviv University (Israel), Reichman University (Israel), University of Toronto (Canada)

study_details.participant_demographics: Completers (n=14): Mean age 51.9 years (SD=15.3), 6 females, 8 males, ages 27-73. Dropout (n=12): Mean age 46.5 years (SD=11.5), 2 females, 10 males
study_details.duration: 14 days recommended, completed in average 15.42 days (SD=11.4). Daily training 3-4 minutes
study_details.target_population: Patients diagnosed with constant (subjective and non-pulsatile) tinnitus lasting more than 3 months

study_content.summary: This pilot open trial assessed the effectiveness of GGTI (GG Tinnitus) mobile app from the GGtude platform in reducing tinnitus-related distress and handicap. The app targets maladaptive beliefs specifically associated with tinnitus (e.g., catastrophic misinterpretations of tinnitus symptoms). 14 out of 26 participants completed all 48 levels of the app. Assessments were conducted using the Hebrew Tinnitus Handicap Inventory (H-THI) and Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) for mood at three time points.
key_findings: Significant large-effect size reduction on H-THI scores (F=14.5, p=0.002, d=2.12)
50% of completers (7 out of 14) showed reliable change based on RCI scores
85% of completers (12 out of 14) showed amelioration in THI scores
No significant change in mood (VAS scores) across assessment occasions
Age did not hamper positive effects - even participants over 65 years showed improvements
Dropout rate of 46% (12 out of 26)
All completers reported vertigo, versus 75% of dropouts (p=.05)

measurable_improvements.result: Steady decrease across time: T1 M=28.57, T2 M=22.14, T3 M=22.0
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Large: Cohen's d = 2.12
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: 50% of completers (7/14) showed reliable change, with 1 additional participant showing RCI of 1.5

measurable_improvements.result: No significant change across time points (F=0.27, p=.61)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Not applicable
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Not applicable

study_content.statistical_significance: Significant linear trend for H-THI: F(1,13)=14.5, p=0.002, d=2.12. No significant correlations between improvement and duration of tinnitus, baseline mood, or days to completion.

core_information.study_title: Cognitive training using a mobile app as a coping tool against COVID-19 distress: A crossover randomized controlled trial
core_information.affiliations: Baskent University, Hacettepe University (Turkey), Reichman University (Israel)

study_details.study_type: Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) with crossover design
study_details.participant_demographics: iApp group (n=25, 19 females, Mean age=26.84, SD=8.72), dApp group (n=22, 17 females, Mean age=25.86, SD=10.39)
study_details.duration: 12 days intervention per group, assessments at T0, T1 (12 days), and T2 (24 days)
study_details.target_population: Community participants with elevated COVID-19 distress (scoring 2 SD above mean on CDS during pandemic)

study_content.summary: This RCT evaluated the GGcov module of the GGtude platform in reducing COVID-19-related distress during the pandemic. Using a crossover design, participants were randomized into immediate-app use (iApp) and delayed-app use (dApp) groups. Participants completed 3 levels per day (approximately 3-4 minutes) for 12 consecutive days, targeting maladaptive cognitions associated with COVID-19 distress.
key_findings: Large effect-size reductions in COVID-19 distress (Cohen's d ranging from 1.74 to 2.35)

Marginally significant effects on intolerance of uncertainty (IUS-12, p = .06)

Overall dropout rate of 17%

core_information.study_title: A Smartphone Intervention for People With Serious Mental Illness: Fully Remote Randomized Controlled Trial of CORE
core_information.affiliations: University of Washington (USA), Dartmouth College (USA), Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (Israel)

study_details.study_type: Fully remote Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) with crossover waitlist design
study_details.participant_demographics: 315 participants from 45 US states, mostly female (83.8%), White (76.5%), ages 18-78 years (Mean age Active=38.98, SD=12.30; Waitlist=36.85, SD=10.91). Unemployed (66.7%), living independently (47.6%) or with family (43.2%)
study_details.duration: 30 days intervention per group, assessments at baseline (T1), 30 days (T2), and 60 days (T3)
study_details.target_population: People with serious mental illness: schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder (21.6%), bipolar disorder (35.2%), major depressive disorder (43.2%), with moderate to severe symptoms and disability

study_content.summary: This was the first fully remote RCT of an mHealth intervention for people with serious mental illness. The CORE app uses the GGtude platform with daily brief game-like exercises designed to promote reassessment of dysfunctional beliefs in multiple domains relevant to SMI. Participants were recruited entirely via web (Google and Facebook ads), randomized to active intervention or waitlist control groups. The intervention comprised 53 levels covering domains: self-talk, belief in change, self-stigma, self-care, self-worth, illness and identity, personal strength, social avoidance, feelings vs facts, catastrophization, thoughts of reference, paranoid ideation, treatment seeking, and recovery. Participants completed up to 3 levels per day (3-4 minutes) for 30 days.
key_findings: Successfully demonstrated feasibility of fully remote clinical trials in SMI population - recruited from 45 states including 80% of most rural states
Significant treatment×time interactions: BDI-II (F=13.38, p<.001), GAD-7 (F=5.87, p=.01), RAS (F=23.42, p<.001), RSES (F=19.28, p<.001), SDS (F=10.73, p=.001)
Large effect sizes: BDI-II (d=0.58), RAS (d=0.61), RSES (d=0.64)
Moderate effect: SDS (d=0.44), Small effect: GAD-7 (d=0.20)
Results replicated in waitlist control group following crossover (T2 to T3)
Improvements maintained at follow-up with additional small effects on GPTS, RAS, and SDS
No significant effects on auditory hallucinations (HPSVQ)
CORE rated as highly usable and acceptable - 95% found it easy to use, 84.9% satisfied, 75.6% would recommend to friend
50.6% of participants with app data completed all 53 intervention levels (average 35 levels)
High dropout rates: Active group 41.5% retained at T2, 33.1% at T3; Waitlist group 60.2% retained at T2, 40.3% at T3
Recruitment cost-effective: $2,984.26 total budget, recruited 315 participants via Google (71.7%) and Facebook ads

measurable_improvements.result: Active group: significant reduction from T1 (M=33.46) to T2 (M=26.33) to T3 (M=24.94). Waitlist replicated T2 to T3
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Large: Cohen's d=0.58 to 0.60; Between-group F(1,313)=13.38, p<.001

core_information.study_title: Can self-esteem be improved using short daily training on mobile applications? Examining real world data of GG Self-esteem users
core_information.affiliations: Concordia University (Canada), Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology Interdisciplinary Center (Israel)

study_details.study_type: Real world data analysis (retrospective observational study)
study_details.participant_demographics: 5,320 users who downloaded GGSE organically through Google Play or Apple Store. Mean age 26.55 years (SD=10.56, range 9-88), 75.4% male. 71.7% from English-speaking countries (U.S. 41.4%, Great Britain 21.2%, Canada 3.5%, Australia 2.8%, India 2%, New Zealand 0.9%)
study_details.duration: Three assessment points: Level 1 (baseline), Level 20 (n=1,034, 19.4% retention), Level 46 (n=165, 15.9% of Level 20). Mean 9.90 days from baseline to Level 20 for non-completers, 5.15 days for completers. Mean 14.99 days from Level 20 to Level 46
study_details.target_population: General population users of GG Self-esteem mobile application seeking to improve self-esteem

study_content.summary: This study examined real-world data from users of the GG Self-esteem mobile application between January 2019 and August 2019. The app consists of 46 levels (first 15 free, remaining require payment) targeting self-esteem relevant maladaptive beliefs such as self-criticism, negative thinking, and self-efficacy. Users complete brief daily training sessions where they are presented with statement 'blocks' that they either embrace (pull downward) or reject (throw upward). The intervention targets beliefs about self-talk, belief in change, self-stigma, self-care, self-worth, illness and identity, personal strength, social avoidance, feelings versus facts, catastrophization, thoughts of reference, paranoid ideation, treatment seeking, and recovery. Self-esteem was assessed using the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale at three time points, and mood was assessed using a Visual Analogue Scale with five face icons.
key_findings: Significant dosage-response effect: Higher levels of app completion associated with greater self-esteem improvements
Self-esteem ratings significantly increased across all three assessment points (Levels 1, 20, and 46)
Large effect size for self-esteem improvement from baseline to Level 46 (Cohen's d = 1.38)
Moderate effect size for self-esteem from baseline to Level 20 (Cohen's d = 1.26)
Mood ratings significantly improved from baseline to Level 20 (Cohen's d = .50) but not from Level 20 to Level 46
Gender differences: Men showed significantly higher self-esteem scores than women at baseline and Level 20, but not at Level 46
Age effects: Older users (M=32.64, SD=10.45) more likely to complete training than younger users (M=25.77, SD=10.09)
High dropout rates typical of eHealth interventions: 80.6% dropped before Level 20, 84.1% of Level 20 completers dropped before Level 46
Completers took fewer days to complete training than non-completers (5.15 vs 9.90 days from baseline to Level 20)
Real-world data findings consistent with previous controlled trials of GGApps platform

measurable_improvements.result: Significant increase from M=14.14 (SD=5.01) at baseline to M=16.91 (SD=5.08) at Level 20
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: 19.4% of baseline users completed Level 20

measurable_improvements.result: Progressive increase: Baseline M=14.14 (SD=5.01), Level 20 M=16.91 (SD=5.08), Level 46 M=18.01 (SD=5.11)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Very large: Cohen's d = 1.38; F(2,314) = 74.96, p ≤ .001
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: 3.1% of baseline users (165/5,320) completed all 46 levels

measurable_improvements.result: Significant increase from M=3.13 (SD=0.88) to M=3.44 (SD=0.90)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Improvement sustained at Level 20

measurable_improvements.result: Increased at Level 20 (M=3.44, SD=0.90) compared to baseline (M=3.13, SD=0.88), but no further improvement at Level 46 (M=3.32, SD=0.96)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Moderate baseline to Level 20: Cohen's d = .41; F(2,314) = 6.77, p ≤ .001
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: No significant differences between Level 20 and Level 46

measurable_improvements.result: Men showed higher self-esteem than women at baseline (Men: M=14.97, Women: M=13.85) and Level 20 (Men: M=17.92, Women: M=16.55), but not at Level 46
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Main effect of gender F(1,1017) = 20.71, p < .001 (baseline to Level 20)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Gender differences diminished with continued app use

study_content.statistical_significance: Repeated-measures ANOVAs conducted with Bonferroni correction for post hoc comparisons. Age included as covariate in gender analyses. Multiple imputation not used as this was real-world observational data. Mauchly's test confirmed sphericity assumption was not violated.

core_information.study_title: Cognitive Behavioral Training Using a Mobile Application Reduces Body Image-Related Symptoms in High-Risk Female University Students: A Randomized Controlled Study
core_information.affiliations: University of Padova (Italy), Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (Israel)

study_details.study_type: Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) with crossover design
study_details.participant_demographics: 50 female university students aged 20-25 years (Mean age=21.74, SD=1.35) at high-risk of developing body image disorders (BIDs). iApp group n=25, dApp group n=25. No differences in BMI, demographics, or baseline symptoms between groups
study_details.duration: 16 days intervention per group with assessments at baseline (T0), 16 days (T1), and 32 days (T2). Participants completed 3 levels per day (approximately 3 minutes daily) for 16 consecutive days
study_details.target_population: Female university students at high-risk of developing body image disorders (BIDs), defined as QDC score >130 (extreme body dissatisfaction/BDD symptoms) or EDRC score >47 (ED risk)

study_content.summary: This RCT assessed the efficacy of GGBI (GG Body Image: Positive Body Image), a mobile application based on cognitive behavioral principles, in reducing body dissatisfaction and BDD/ED symptoms in high-risk female university students. GGBI consists of 48 levels (3 levels per belief) targeting maladaptive beliefs such as perfectionism, fear of being judged, importance of physical appearance, body as an object, self-criticism, and negative thinking. Users are presented with statement 'blocks' that they either embrace (pull downward) or reject (push upward). The app includes psychoeducation before each new belief, feedback based on completion time, and memory-boost games. Participants were randomized to immediate-use (iApp) or delayed-use (dApp) groups using a crossover design. Recruitment involved screening 240 students, identifying 53 at high-risk, excluding 3 with full-blown BIDs or current treatment, resulting in 50 participants.
key_findings: Significant Group × Time interaction on BDD symptoms (QDC): iApp group showed greater decrease than dApp group from T0 to T1 (F=5.81, p=.02, ηp²=.12, medium effect size)
Post-intervention means for BDD symptoms fell below cut-off (<130) for extreme body dissatisfaction/BDD symptoms in both groups
No significant Group × Time interaction for ED symptoms (DT, B, EDRC), though main Time effect approached significance for BD subscale (p=.05)
100% adherence rate: All 50 participants completed entire 16-day training and all assessments at T0, T1, and T2
iApp group showed significant reductions from T0 to T2 on QDC (p=.03, ηp²=.13) and BD subscale (p=.01, ηp²=.16)
Trends toward significance for DT (p=.05) and EDRC (p=.05) in iApp group
dApp group replicated results after crossover with large effect reductions on QDC (p<.001, ηp²=.42) and BD (p=.04, ηp²=.16)
Effects on ED symptoms were more limited than effects on body dissatisfaction

Training targeted 16 maladaptive beliefs including self-talk, belief in change, self-stigma, self-care, self-worth, illness and identity, personal strength, social avoidance, feelings vs facts, catastrophization, thoughts of reference, paranoid ideation, treatment seeking, and recovery
No participants dropped out, demonstrating excellent feasibility and acceptability

measurable_improvements.result: iApp group decreased from M=144.96 (SD=25.99) at T0 to M=128.72 (SD=29.72) at T1; dApp group increased from M=141.40 (SD=27.52) to M=144.84 (SD=30.81)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant Group × Time interaction favoring iApp group

measurable_improvements.metric: BDD Symptoms (QDC) - iApp Group Across Time
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant reduction maintained at follow-up

measurable_improvements.metric: BDD Symptoms (QDC) - dApp Group After Crossover
measurable_improvements.result: Decreased from T1 M=144.84 (SD=30.81) to T2 M=125.72 (SD=32.53)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Results replicated in waitlist group after intervention

measurable_improvements.metric: Body Dissatisfaction - ED related (EDI-3 BD) - iApp Group
measurable_improvements.result: Decreased from T0 M=25.40 (SD=9.37) to T1 M=22.16 (SD=10.71) to T2 M=21.04 (SD=11.04), with significant T0 to T2 reduction (p=.04)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant reductions in shape and body part concerns

measurable_improvements.metric: Body Dissatisfaction - ED related (EDI-3 BD) - dApp Group
measurable_improvements.result: Decreased from T1 M=22.64 (SD=10.25) to T2 M=21.08 (SD=10.82)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant reduction after crossover

measurable_improvements.result: Trend toward significance in iApp group: T0 M=16.88 to T1 M=14.92 to T2 M=13.64; dApp group approached significance T1 to T2 (p=.06)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Medium: ηp²=.12 to .14; approaching significance p=.05-.06
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Trends toward reduction in both groups, not statistically significant

measurable_improvements.result: Trend toward significance in iApp group from T0 M=50.76 to T2 M=41.92; dApp group T1 to T2 approached significance (p=.06)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Medium: ηp²=.12 to .13; approaching significance p=.05-.06
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Trends toward reduction, not reaching statistical significance

measurable_improvements.result: No significant changes in either group across time points
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Not significant
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Not applicable

study_content.statistical_significance: Repeated-measures ANOVAs used for analysis. Between-group comparisons: 2 (Group) × 2 (Time) ANOVAs. Within-group: 1 × 3 (Time) ANOVAs for iApp group, 1 × 2 (Time) for dApp crossover. Effect sizes: ηp²=.01 (small), ηp²=.06 (medium), ηp²=.14 (large). No missing data as all participants completed training and assessments. Bonferroni corrections applied for post-hoc comparisons.

core_information.study_title: Building resilience to body image triggers using brief cognitive training on a mobile application: A randomized controlled trial
core_information.affiliations: Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (Israel), Department of Psychology Swarthmore College (USA)

study_details.participant_demographics: Female undergraduate students aged 19-28 years (Mean age=23.52, SD=1.45), all heterosexual. GGBI group n=48, Control group n=42. No significant differences at baseline on demographics or measures
study_details.duration: 14 days (2 weeks) of training, approximately 4 minutes per day. Assessments at baseline, post-test (15-21 days after baseline), and 1-month follow-up
study_details.target_population: Non-clinical sample of women with body image concerns who used Instagram or Facebook

study_content.summary: This RCT evaluated the GGBI (GG Body Image) mobile app in reducing body image disturbance (BID) symptoms and increasing resilience to body image triggers. Women were randomized to use GGBI for 14 consecutive days (4 min/day) or to a waitlist control condition. The study uniquely assessed resilience by having participants browse Instagram accounts featuring thin-ideal imagery and measuring their state body image responses. The app targets maladaptive beliefs (perfectionism, importance of appearance, viewing body as aesthetic object, uncertainty about looks, media literacy) and promotes positive body image and body appreciation. This is the first study to demonstrate that cognitive training can buffer against harmful effects of naturalistic, life-like Instagram exposure.
key_findings: Significant Group × Time multivariate interaction for all primary body image measures (Pillai's trace=.29, F(6,83)=5.54, p<.001, d=1.27)
GGBI users showed medium-to-large effect size improvements on all trait body image measures
All effects maintained at 1-month follow-up
98.9% retention rate: Only 1 participant (out of 90) did not complete follow-up assessment
GGBI participants showed increased resilience to Instagram thin-ideal exposure: greater appearance satisfaction and less body anxiety after browsing Instagram
Resilience effects maintained at 1-month follow-up
Only 2 out of 48 GGBI participants did not reach highest app level (54); both completed at least 40 levels
Improvements in self-esteem maintained at follow-up
Depression did not improve significantly (sample had low baseline depression)
No group differences in negative mood after Instagram exposure

measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant reductions maintained at follow-up in GGBI group

Resilience effects sustained at 1-month follow-up

measurable_improvements.result: After Instagram exposure, GGBI group showed less anxiety about body parts than control group

study_content.statistical_significance: Mixed two-way MANOVAs with Time (baseline/post/follow-up) as within-subject factor and Group (GGBI/control) as between-subject factor. One-way ANOVAs for state measures. Bonferroni adjustments applied. Effect sizes: small d=0.2, medium d=0.5, large d=0.8. Power analysis showed 80% power to detect large effects (f>0.35) with n=92. Last-observation-carried-forward for 1 missing follow-up participant.

core_information.study_title: Reaching reliable change using short, daily, cognitive training exercises delivered on a mobile application: The case of Relationship Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (ROCD) symptoms and cognitions in a subclinical cohort
core_information.affiliations: Department of General Psychology University of Padova (Italy), Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (Israel)

study_details.study_type: Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) with crossover design
study_details.participant_demographics: 50 university students (76% females) aged 20-24 years (Mean age=22, SD=1.32). Immediate-use app group (iApp) n=25, Delayed-use app group (dApp) n=25. No significant differences at baseline on demographics or measures
study_details.duration: 15 days intervention per group, 3 levels per day (approximately 3 minutes daily). Assessments at baseline (T0), 15 days (T1), and 30 days (T2)
study_details.target_population: University students with subclinical ROCD symptoms (scoring above clinical threshold on ROCI >21.5 or PROCSI >17, but not meeting full diagnosis of ROCD on SCID-5-CV). Participants had experienced at least one romantic relationship

study_content.summary: This RCT assessed the efficacy of GG Relationship Doubts (GGRO) mobile app from the GGtude platform in reducing ROCD symptoms, OCD beliefs, and associated features in university students with subclinical ROCD concerns. GGRO consists of 45 levels (3 levels per belief) targeting maladaptive beliefs associated with ROCD including intolerance of uncertainty, perfectionism, inflated responsibility, importance of thoughts, and control of thoughts. Participants were randomized to immediate-use (iApp) or delayed-use (dApp) groups using a crossover design. The study uniquely evaluated reliable change using the Reliable Change Index (RCI), demonstrating that 40-52% of participants achieved reliable change on ROCD symptoms. This is the first study to assess GGRO effects in a subclinical ROCD sample using structured diagnostic interview screening.
key_findings: Significant Group × Time multivariate interaction (F[1,48]=2.82, p=.01, ηp²=.50) with large effect sizes
40% of participants achieved reliable change on relationship-centered ROCD symptoms (ROCI)
52% achieved reliable change on partner-focused ROCD symptoms (PROCSI)
Medium-large effect size reductions in all OCD-related beliefs (OBQ-46 subscales)
32% achieved reliable change on general OCD symptoms (OCI-R)
Significant increases in self-esteem (12% reliable change) maintained at follow-up
Significant reductions in social anxiety symptoms (18% reliable change)
Excellent retention: 100% completed post-test, 98.9% completed follow-up (only 1 dropout)
All effects maintained at 2-week follow-up in iApp group
Results replicated in dApp group after crossover
Only 2 out of 48 GGBI participants did not reach highest app level (45); both completed at least 40 levels
No significant effects on intolerance of uncertainty in dApp group (though 10% showed reliable change)

measurable_improvements.result: iApp group: Baseline M=21.08 (SD=8.70) to Post M=13.76 (SD=10.56) to Follow-up M=12.32 (SD=9.56). dApp group showed similar reductions after crossover
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Large: Group × Time ηp²=.17, F(1,48)=9.58, p=.003; Within iApp ηp²=.42, Cohen's d=.76 to .96
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: 40% of participants (13 iApp + 7 dApp) achieved reliable change from pre- to post-training
