study_content.statistical_significance: Repeated-measures MANOVAs and ANOVAs with Bonferroni corrections. Reliable Change Index (RCI) calculated using Jacobson and Truax (1991) method. Block randomization with fixed block size of two. All participants completed required questionnaires at T0, T1, and T2, and entire GGRO training - no missing data. Effect sizes: ηp²=.01 (small), ηp²=.06 (medium), ηp²=.14 (large). Power analysis showed 80% power to detect large effects (f>0.35) with n=92.

core_information.publication_name: Journal of Behavior Therapy and Experimental Psychiatry
core_information.study_title: A novel approach to challenging OCD related beliefs using a mobile-app: An exploratory study
core_information.affiliations: Department of Personality, Faculty of Psychology, Research and Treatment Unit for Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders (I'TOC) University of Valencia (Spain), Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology Interdisciplinary Center (IDC) Herzliya (Israel)

study_details.study_type: Open trial (exploratory study with no control group)
study_details.participant_demographics: 20 completers (16 women, 4 men) from initial 36 enrolled. Ages 19-26 years (Median=21). 9 in romantic relationships (median length 17.95 months). Mostly average socioeconomic status (75%). Third-year BA students at University of Valencia. 44% dropout rate (16 non-completers)
study_details.duration: 15 days of training, 3 minutes per day (3 levels daily). Pre- and post-treatment assessments only, no follow-up
study_details.target_population: Non-clinical university students. No specific OCD diagnosis required - general student population

study_content.summary: This exploratory open trial was the first study to evaluate the GGRO (GG Relationship Obsession) mobile app from the GGtude platform. The app uses a novel approach where users physically interact with statements by pulling adaptive statements downward (toward themselves) and throwing maladaptive statements upward (away from themselves). GGRO consists of 45 levels targeting OCD-related maladaptive beliefs including inflated responsibility, importance of thoughts, control of thoughts, overestimation of threat, need for certainty, and perfectionism. Each new belief set includes psychoeducational rationale. The app includes memory quizzes after each level, push notifications for daily reminders, and discourages use in response to distressing thoughts. This proof-of-concept study assessed pre-post changes in OCD beliefs, OCD symptoms (including relationship-obsessions), and mood in non-clinical students.
key_findings: Significant multivariate effect across all measures (Pillai's trace=.964, F(5,15)=5.27, p=.005, d=0.72)
Large effect size reductions on all OCD symptom measures and OCD-related beliefs
No significant reduction in depression symptoms
Pre-post changes in OCD beliefs significantly predicted reduction in OCD symptoms (β=-.53, p<.05)
Change in beliefs accounted for 17% additional variance in OCD symptoms beyond baseline symptoms
No significant differences between completers (n=20) and non-completers (n=16) on demographics or most baseline measures
44% dropout rate (16 of 36 participants did not complete)
Small to null effect sizes for differences between completers and non-completers (except PROCSI d=.42)
All completers reported using the app for more than 12 days as required
Results support dimensional view of OCD beliefs and symptoms

measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant reduction in pan-situational OCD-related cognitions
Highly significant reduction in overall OCD symptoms
Significant reduction in relationship-centered obsessive symptoms
Significant reduction in partner-focused obsessive symptoms

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Small, not significant: F(1,19)=1.69, p=.21, Cohen's d=0.23
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: No significant changes in depressive symptoms

measurable_improvements.metric: Predictive relationship: OCD Beliefs → OCD Symptoms
measurable_improvements.result: Change in OBQ-20 scores (T1-T2) significantly predicted OCI-R at T2, controlling for OCI-R at T1
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: 17% additional variance explained by belief change beyond baseline symptoms

study_content.statistical_significance: Repeated-measures MANOVA conducted. Hierarchical regression used to test predictive relationships. Internal consistency adequate to high across all measures at pre (α=.81 to .95) and post (α=.72 to .93). Chi-square and t-tests used for completer vs non-completer comparisons. Effect sizes calculated using Cohen's d.

core_information.study_title: Assisting relapse prevention in OCD using a novel mobile app-based intervention: A case report
core_information.affiliations: Department of Personality, Faculty of Psychology, Research and Treatment Unit for Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders (I'TOC) University of Valencia (Spain), Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology Interdisciplinary Center (IDC) Herzliya (Israel)

study_details.participant_demographics: 26-year-old White woman ('Joan' - pseudonym). Unemployed, living with parents, university educated, had boyfriend for 1 year. Presented with severe treatment-resistant OCD (contamination obsessions, washing/cleaning compulsions) for 5+ years. Comorbid major depression secondary to OCD. Mother had partially remitted major depressive disorder. Traveled 400km one-way weekly for treatment.
study_details.duration: 2 weeks (14 days) of GGOC app use following 8 months of CBT (32 weekly sessions). Patient completed 47 levels of the app. GGOC used as substitute for usual 2 face-to-face relapse prevention sessions. 2-year follow-up conducted.
study_details.target_population: Individual with severe, treatment-resistant OCD who achieved recovery following CBT and needed relapse prevention support

study_content.summary: This single-case study evaluated the efficacy of the GGOC mobile app as a relapse prevention tool for a patient with severe OCD who had successfully completed CBT treatment. The patient (Joan) initially presented with Y-BOCS=33 (severe), contamination obsessions, and washing/cleaning compulsions occupying 3-5 hours daily. After 32 sessions of CBT combined with pharmacotherapy, she achieved recovery (Y-BOCS=7). GGOC was then used for 2 weeks as a relapse prevention intervention. The app consists of 47 levels targeting OCD-relevant maladaptive beliefs through game-like interactions where users pull adaptive statements toward themselves and push maladaptive statements away. The study assessed changes in OCD symptoms, beliefs, and depression before and after GGOC use.
key_findings: Y-BOCS decreased from 7 (post-CBT/pre-GGOC) to 2 (post-GGOC), indicating sustained recovery
All OBQ-20 subscales (OCD beliefs) showed reductions from pre- to post-GGOC
OCI-R symptoms decreased for cleaning/washing and neutralizing subscales, as well as total score
DASS depression scores remained stable and low (8/21 at both time points) - patient had already recovered from depression after CBT
Patient remained free of OCD and depressive symptoms at 2-year follow-up
Patient reported app was accessible, easy to use, and served as useful reminder of therapy learnings
GGOC successfully maintained and increased therapeutic gains from CBT
App provided cost-effective relapse prevention alternative to face-to-face sessions for patient with travel barriers

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Clinically significant improvement maintained and enhanced
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Met Jacobson & Truax (1991) criteria for recovery (Y-BOCS ≤7 plus ≥6 point decrease from baseline)

measurable_improvements.result: Decreased from Pre-GGOC to Post-GGOC across all subscales
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Reductions observed in responsibility/threat estimation, perfectionism/certainty, and importance/control of thoughts
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Largest reduction (3.2 points) in importance/control of thoughts subscale - one of patient's most endorsed beliefs

measurable_improvements.result: Reduced from pre-relapse prevention to post-relapse prevention
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Clinically meaningful reduction in core symptom domain
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Addressed patient's primary OCD presentation (contamination fears)

measurable_improvements.result: Reduced from pre-relapse prevention to post-relapse prevention
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Reduction in neutralizing behaviors
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Improvement in compulsive mental rituals

measurable_improvements.result: Overall reduction from pre- to post-GGOC use
measurable_improvements.effect_size: General improvement across OCD symptom domains
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Maintained gains from CBT and showed additional improvement

measurable_improvements.result: Remained stable at 8/21 (raw score) at both pre- and post-GGOC time points
measurable_improvements.effect_size: No change - already at low level after CBT
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Patient had fully recovered from comorbid major depression during CBT

measurable_improvements.result: Patient remained completely free of OCD and depressive symptoms
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Complete maintenance of treatment gains over extended period
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: No relapse observed - demonstrates long-term efficacy of GGOC for relapse prevention

study_content.statistical_significance: As a single-case study, no statistical tests were conducted. Clinical significance was evaluated using Y-BOCS criteria (Jacobson & Truax, 1991: Y-BOCS ≤7 plus ≥6 point decrease). Patient met recovery criteria after CBT and maintained/enhanced gains after GGOC. Long-term maintenance confirmed at 2-year follow-up. Pre-post comparisons on self-report measures (OBQ-20, OCI-R, DASS) showed consistent improvements in OCD-related domains.

core_information.study_title: Can Brief, Daily Training Using a Mobile App Help Change Maladaptive Beliefs? Crossover Randomized Controlled Trial
core_information.affiliations: Research and Treatment Unit for Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders, Department of Personality, Faculty of Psychology, University of Valencia (Spain), Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology, Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (Israel)

study_details.participant_demographics: 97 university students (79 women, 81.4%). Ages 18-65 years (mean 21.56, SD 7.07). Second and third-year BA students. 61.9% medium socioeconomic status (28.9% below average, 9.3% above average). 56.3% in romantic relationship at time of study (median relationship length 33 months). Native Spanish speakers with at least one stable romantic relationship experience.
study_details.duration: 15 days of app use (3 levels per day, ~3 minutes daily). Assessment at T1 (baseline), T2 (15 days), T3 (30 days). iApp group used app from T1-T2, then 15-day follow-up. dApp group waited T1-T2 (waitlist), then used app T2-T3 (crossover). 81.4% completed T2, 65.1% completed T3.
study_details.target_population: Non-clinical university students from University of Valencia. No specific OCD diagnosis required - general student population with OCD-related beliefs and symptoms

study_content.summary: This crossover randomized controlled trial evaluated the efficacy of GGRO (GG Relationship Obsession) mobile app in reducing OCD-related maladaptive beliefs and symptoms in non-clinical students. 97 participants were randomized to immediate-use app group (iApp, n=51) or delayed-use app group (dApp, n=46). The iApp group used GGRO for 15 consecutive days starting at baseline, then stopped for 15-day follow-up. The dApp group served as waitlist control for first 15 days, then crossed over to use the app for 15 days. GGRO consists of 45 levels (3 levels per belief) targeting OCD-related maladaptive beliefs through game-like interactions. Users pull adaptive statements toward themselves and push maladaptive statements away. The app includes psychoeducational rationales, memory quizzes, push notifications, and encourages daily preset-time training (not in response to distressing thoughts). This study built upon a previous exploratory open trial and aimed to confirm efficacy with stronger methodology.
key_findings: All participants used app for mean 14.07 days (SD 1.41) with 2.94 levels per day
Mean highest level completed: 40.93 of 45 levels (91% completion)
Significant treatment × time interactions favoring iApp group: OBQ-20 (beliefs), PROCSI-Si (partner-focused ROCD), and SISE (self-esteem)
iApp group showed medium-large effect size reductions maintained at 15-day follow-up
dApp group replicated results after crossover with significant reductions in all OCD measures
Largest effect sizes for OCD beliefs: iApp d=1.42, dApp d=1.07
Partner-focused ROCD symptoms showed continued improvement at follow-up (additional gains between T2-T3)
No significant changes in depression symptoms (DASS) - expected as app targets OCD-specific beliefs
Unexpected: dApp group showed some OCD symptom reduction during waitlist period (possibly due to mid-semester timing with fewer evaluations)
Intention-to-treat analysis with last-observation-carried-forward method used

measurable_improvements.result: Significant treatment × time interaction at T1 vs T2
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: iApp group showed greater reduction in OCD-related beliefs than dApp waitlist group
Very large reduction in maladaptive beliefs sustained at follow-up

measurable_improvements.metric: OBQ-20 (OCD Beliefs) - dApp Within-Group After Crossover
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Replicated large effect after crossover to app use
Medium-large reduction in OCD symptoms maintained at follow-up

measurable_improvements.effect_size: T1→T2: F(1,45)=7.28, P=.01, d=0.56 (unexpected waitlist effect); T2→T3: F(1,45)=9.09, P=.004, d=0.61 (additional app effect)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Continued reduction during app use despite waitlist improvement
Medium effect on relationship-centered obsessive symptoms
Replicated effect with larger magnitude after crossover

measurable_improvements.result: Significant treatment × time interaction at T1 vs T2
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: iApp group showed greater reduction than dApp waitlist
Large effect with additional significant improvement during follow-up - suggests generalization
Replicated medium-large effect after crossover

measurable_improvements.result: Significant treatment × time interaction at T1 vs T2
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: iApp group showed greater increase in self-esteem than dApp waitlist
Medium improvement in self-esteem maintained at follow-up
Replicated medium effect with identical effect size after crossover

measurable_improvements.result: No significant changes in either group at any time point
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: No effect on depression - expected as GGRO targets OCD-specific beliefs, not depression-related beliefs (hopelessness, helplessness)

study_content.statistical_significance: Crossover RCT design with intention-to-treat analysis using last-observation-carried-forward method. Repeated measures ANOVA with Bonferroni adjustments performed. Between-group analyses (T1 vs T2) revealed significant treatment × repeated measures interactions for OBQ-20, PROCSI-Si, and SISE. Within-group analyses showed significant pre-post reductions in iApp group maintained at T3 follow-up. dApp group replicated results after crossover (T2→T3). Effect sizes calculated using Cohen's d. Sample size: 97 randomized, 79 completed T2 (81.4%), 62 completed T3 (65.1%). No significant differences in dropouts vs completers on demographics. Trial registered: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT03571464.

core_information.study_title: Can self-esteem be improved using short daily training on mobile applications? Examining real world data of GG Self-esteem users
core_information.affiliations: Department of Psychology, Concordia University, Montreal (Canada), Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology Interdisciplinary Center (IDC) Herzliya (Israel)

study_details.study_type: Real world data analysis / Retrospective observational study
study_details.participant_demographics: 5,320 users who downloaded GGSE organically through Google Play or Apple Store. Mean age 26.55 years (SD=10.56, range 9-88). 75.4% men, 24.6% women. 71.7% from English-speaking countries: US (41.4%), Great Britain (21.2%), Canada (3.5%), Australia (2.8%), India (2%), New Zealand (0.9%). Completers of Level 46 were significantly older (M=32.64, SD=10.45) than those who dropped after Level 20 (M=29.24, SD=10.88) or baseline (M=25.77, SD=10.09). No gender differences in dropout rates.
study_details.duration: Data collected January 2019 - August 2019. Assessment at 3 time points: Level 1 (baseline, n=5,320), Level 20 (n=1,034, 19.4%), Level 46 (n=165, 15.9% of Level 20 completers). Mean days of use: 9.90 days (SD=13.66) for non-completers to Level 20, 5.15 days (SD=4.79) for completers to Level 20, 14.99 days (SD=15.26) from Level 20 to Level 46. Total approximately 20 days average to complete all 46 levels.
study_details.target_population: Real-world users of GG Self-esteem app seeking to improve self-esteem. Organic downloads (not recruited for research). Anonymous data collection (no username/password required). General population with self-esteem concerns.

study_content.summary: This real-world data study examined whether brief, daily use of the GGSE (GG Self-esteem) mobile app was associated with improvements in self-esteem and mood ratings in a naturalistic setting. GGSE is a CBT-based app consisting of 46 levels (3 levels per belief) targeting maladaptive beliefs associated with low self-esteem such as self-criticism, negative thinking, perfectionism, self-efficacy, dealing with emotions, social fears, and abandonment fears. Users pull adaptive statements toward themselves and throw maladaptive statements away. The app includes tutorials, psychoeducational rationales, memory quizzes, and assessment levels. First 15 levels are free; additional levels require payment. Data from 5,320 users were retrospectively analyzed to assess dosage-response effects across three assessment points (Levels 1, 20, and 46). The Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSES) was embedded as 'assessment-quiz' levels, and mood was assessed using a 5-point Visual Analogue Scale with face icons. This study tested whether findings from previous controlled trials would replicate in real-world conditions without research incentives or monitoring.
key_findings: Very large real-world sample: 5,320 initial users organically downloaded the app
Significant dosage-response effect: Higher app levels associated with greater self-esteem improvements
Large effect size for self-esteem across all levels: Cohen's d = 1.26 (baseline to Level 20), d = 1.38 (baseline to Level 46)
Self-esteem continued to improve from Level 20 to Level 46, demonstrating sustained benefit with continued use
Mood improved from baseline to Level 20 (d=0.50, medium effect) but plateaued (no further improvement from Level 20 to 46)
High dropout rates: 80.6% before Level 20, 84.1% before Level 46 - typical for mHealth interventions
Older users more likely to complete training (age effect on completion)
Gender differences: Men showed higher self-esteem than women at baseline and Level 20 (consistent with literature)
Payment barrier at Level 15 likely contributed to dropout rates
Real-world results consistent with previous RCTs, demonstrating ecological validity
Users completed training over average of 20 days without research incentives

measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant increase in self-esteem with 2.77-point improvement in large real-world sample (n=1,034)

measurable_improvements.metric: RSES (Self-Esteem) - Baseline to Level 46 (3 time points)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: F(2,314)=74.96, P≤.001, Cohen's d=1.38 (large); All pairwise comparisons significant with Bonferroni correction
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Continued improvement across all assessment points - dosage-response effect confirmed. Total 3.87-point improvement (27.4% increase from baseline)
Significant improvement in mood ratings associated with early app use

measurable_improvements.metric: Mood VAS - Baseline to Level 46 (3 time points)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: F(2,314)=6.77, P≤.001, Cohen's d=0.41 (moderate overall); Level 20 vs Level 46: no significant difference
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Mood improved only from baseline to Level 20 (focusing on basic self-concepts), then plateaued. No further improvement with advanced levels (focusing on complex appraisals like perfectionism, social/abandonment fears)

measurable_improvements.metric: Gender Differences in Self-Esteem - Baseline to Level 20
measurable_improvements.result: Main effect of gender: F(1,1017)=20.71, P<.001; Time × Gender interaction: F(1,1017)=0.03, P=.85
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Men showed higher self-esteem than women at both time points; parallel improvement trajectories
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Gender gap maintained across intervention - men consistently reported higher self-esteem (consistent with developmental literature)

measurable_improvements.result: Baseline: Women M=13.85 (SD=5.00), Men M=14.97 (SD=4.99); Level 20: Women M=16.55 (SD=4.97), Men M=17.92 (SD=5.34); Level 46: Women M=17.57 (SD=5.05), Men M=19.26 (SD=5.13)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Main effect time: F(2,310)=6.73, P≤.001, d=0.41; Main effect gender: F(1,155)=2.96, P=.08 (marginal)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Gender difference reduced at Level 46 (no longer statistically significant) - suggests prolonged app use may help reduce gender gap

measurable_improvements.result: Completers of Level 46: M=32.64 (SD=10.45); Dropouts after Level 20: M=29.24 (SD=10.88); Dropouts after baseline: M=25.77 (SD=10.09)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Older users significantly more likely to complete training - possibly due to higher conscientiousness, maturity, financial resources, and motivation to invest in well-being

study_content.statistical_significance: Repeated-measures ANOVAs conducted with Bonferroni corrections for post-hoc comparisons. Factorial repeated-measures ANOVAs with gender as between-subjects factor and age as covariate. F-test robust for Type I error control despite violation of normality assumption. Mauchly's test indicated sphericity assumption was satisfied. All main effects and interactions reported. Excellent internal consistency for RSES (α=.93). Large sample sizes provide adequate power. No attrition analyses showed younger age associated with dropout but no gender differences. Results replicate previous RCTs in real-world setting, demonstrating ecological validity.

core_information.study_title: Building resilience to body image triggers using brief cognitive training on a mobile application: A randomized controlled trial
core_information.affiliations: Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology, Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (Israel), Department of Psychology, Swarthmore College (USA)

study_details.participant_demographics: 90 female undergraduate students aged 19-28 years (M=23.52, SD=1.45), all identified as heterosexual, Hebrew as main language at home, had active Instagram/Facebook accounts. Non-clinical sample. Groups did not differ on demographics or baseline measures. 48 participants randomized to GGBI group, 42 to control group.
study_details.duration: 2 weeks of daily training (approximately 4 minutes/day, 4 levels per day up to level 54) with assessments at baseline, post-test (15-21 days after baseline), and 1-month follow-up. 98.9% retention rate (89/90 completed follow-up). High adherence: 46 of 48 GGBI participants (95.8%) reached highest level (54).
study_details.target_population: Women with body image concerns. Sample recruited from college students via social media and online recruitment system. Eligibility criteria: female-identified, active Instagram/Facebook account, Hebrew speaker, mobile device capable of installing GGBI.

study_content.summary: This RCT evaluated the effects of GGBI (GG Body Image) mobile app on body image disturbance (BID), body appreciation, and resilience to body image triggers. The app consists of short training exercises (4 min/day for 14 days) intended to help women increase accessibility to functional self-statements that facilitate adaptive interpretations of thoughts, emotions, and events associated with body image. The intervention targeted maladaptive beliefs including over-importance of appearance, viewing body as aesthetic object, perfectionism, uncertainty about looks, and media literacy. Users learned to embrace (pull toward themselves) self-statements challenging maladaptive beliefs and promoting positive body image/body appreciation, while rejecting (throwing away) statements consistent with BID-related maladaptive beliefs. Participants completed an Instagram exposure resilience task at post-test and follow-up - browsing a pre-made Instagram account following attractive peers, celebrities, and 'thinspiration' accounts portraying thin-ideal body images for 10 minutes on iPad. To maximize compliance: 2 additional course credits for reaching level 54, lottery entry for two-person massage if no missed days, communications about progress on days 4 and 10.
key_findings: Relative to control group, GGBI participants demonstrated significant improvements on all three primary body image measures (BIDQ, BAS-2, PASTAS-T) with medium-to-large effect sizes
Medium-to-large effect sizes across all measures (Cohen's d ranging from 0.61 to 0.89 for Group X Time interactions)
All improvements maintained at 1-month follow-up assessment

GGBI participants showed increased resilience to Instagram triggers: after viewing thin-ideal Instagram images, they reported significantly greater appearance satisfaction (d=0.56 post-test, d=0.63 follow-up) and less state anxiety about body parts (d=0.44 post-test, d=0.45 follow-up) compared to control group
Self-esteem improved significantly (d=0.55) and gains maintained at follow-up
Depression symptoms did not show significant improvement (not specifically targeted by intervention)
High adherence and low attrition demonstrate feasibility and acceptability of brief mobile intervention
Only 1 participant (1.1%) dropped out at follow-up, indicating excellent retention
Groups did not differ in negative mood following Instagram exposure
No differences between groups in perceived similarity of study Instagram account to personal social media accounts

measurable_improvements.metric: BIDQ (Body Image Disturbance) - Baseline to Post-test
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Group X Time interaction: F(1.85,162.54)=8.15, P=.001, Cohen's d=0.61 (medium)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: GGBI group showed significant reduction in body image disturbance concerns, distress, and impairment. Within GGBI group: F(1,47)=4.12, P<.001, d=0.59. Control group: no significant change.

measurable_improvements.metric: BIDQ (Body Image Disturbance) - Baseline to Follow-up
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within GGBI group: F(1,47)=3.90, P=.006, Cohen's d=0.56 (medium)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Effects maintained at 1-month follow-up. Control group showed non-significant increase in BID symptoms over time.

measurable_improvements.metric: BAS-2 (Body Appreciation Scale) - Baseline to Post-test
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Group X Time interaction: F(1.87,164.25)=9.96, P<.001, Cohen's d=0.67 (medium)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: GGBI group showed significant improvement in positive body image/body appreciation. Within GGBI group: F(1,47)=-4.48, P<.001, d=-0.69. Control group: no change.

measurable_improvements.metric: BAS-2 (Body Appreciation Scale) - Baseline to Follow-up
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within GGBI group: F(1,47)=-4.48, P<.001, Cohen's d=-0.65 (medium)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Body appreciation gains fully maintained at 1-month follow-up. Control group showed non-significant decrease over time. First study to show this mobile platform increases body appreciation.

measurable_improvements.metric: PASTAS-T (Trait Physical Appearance Anxiety) - Baseline to Post-test
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Group X Time interaction: F(1.85,162.84)=17.32, P<.001, Cohen's d=0.89 (large)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: GGBI group showed large reduction in trait anxiety about body parts. Within GGBI group: F(1,47)=4.46, P<.001, d=0.64. Control group: no significant change.

measurable_improvements.metric: PASTAS-T (Trait Physical Appearance Anxiety) - Baseline to Follow-up
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within GGBI group: F(1,47)=5.08, P<.001, Cohen's d=0.71 (medium-large)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Continued improvement maintained at follow-up with further reduction from post-test. Represents 4.84-point reduction from baseline (15.8% decrease).

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Group X Time interaction: F(1.89,165.85)=6.60, P=.002, Cohen's d=0.55 (medium)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: GGBI group showed significant improvement in self-esteem. Within GGBI group: F(1,47)=-4.63, P<.001, d=-0.62. Control group: no significant change.

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within GGBI group: F(1,47)=-3.49, P=.001, Cohen's d=-0.50 (medium)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Self-esteem gains maintained at follow-up. Represents 0.81-point increase (13.8% improvement) sustained 1 month after training ended.

measurable_improvements.metric: PASTAS-S (State Appearance Anxiety after Instagram exposure) - Post-test
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Between-groups comparison: F(1,88)=4.22, P=.04, Cohen's d=0.44 (small-medium)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: After browsing Instagram account with thin-ideal images for 10 minutes, GGBI participants felt significantly less anxious about their body parts compared to control participants. Demonstrates increased resilience to social media triggers.

measurable_improvements.metric: PASTAS-S (State Appearance Anxiety after Instagram exposure) - Follow-up
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Between-groups comparison: F(1,88)=4.47, P=.04, Cohen's d=0.45 (small-medium)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Resilience effects maintained and possibly strengthened at 1-month follow-up. Larger difference between groups at follow-up than post-test.

measurable_improvements.metric: Appearance Satisfaction VAS (after Instagram exposure) - Post-test
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Between-groups comparison: F(1,88)=6.84, P=.01, Cohen's d=0.56 (medium)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: After viewing thin-ideal Instagram images, GGBI participants reported significantly greater satisfaction with their overall appearance, weight, body shape, and face/hair compared to controls (composite VAS 0-100 scale).

measurable_improvements.metric: Appearance Satisfaction VAS (after Instagram exposure) - Follow-up
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Between-groups comparison: F(1,88)=8.57, P=.004, Cohen's d=0.63 (medium)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Resilience to Instagram triggers maintained at 1-month follow-up. GGBI participants continued to show greater body satisfaction after social media exposure compared to controls. Effect size increased from post-test.

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within GGBI group: F(1,47)=2.29, P=.012, d=0.42. Group X Time interaction: not significant
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Depression symptoms did not show significant Group X Time interaction. GGBI group showed some within-group improvement but not maintained at follow-up. Sample had low baseline depression levels; intervention did not specifically target depressogenic beliefs.

study_content.statistical_significance: Power analysis based on previous study (Roncero et al., 2019) indicated 92 participants needed for 80% power at α=.05 with two groups and three measurements to detect large effects (f>0.35) with 10% expected attrition. MANOVAs with Bonferroni adjustments conducted for trait measures. Mixed two-way MANOVAs with Time (baseline/post-test/follow-up) as within-subject factor and Group (GGBI/control) as between-subject factor. One-way ANOVAs for state measures. All primary body image measures showed significant Group X Time interactions with medium-to-large effect sizes. State resilience measures (appearance satisfaction, PASTAS-S) showed significant between-group differences at both post-test and follow-up with small-to-medium effect sizes. Excellent internal consistency for all measures: BIDQ (α=.91-.92), BAS-2 (α=.94-.95), PASTAS-T (α=.87-.88), PASTAS-S (α=.87-.88), DASS-D (α=.87-.88), Appearance Satisfaction VAS (α=.91-.92), Negative Mood VAS (α=.79-.82). Groups did not differ at baseline on any demographic or outcome variables. No differences in daily Instagram (t(78)=0.53, p=.60) or Facebook use (t(84)=0.15, p=.88). No differences in similarity ratings of study Instagram account to personal accounts (post-test: t=0.027, p=.87; follow-up: t=0.720, p=.40). Trial registered at https://osf.io/gfzke. Last-observation-carried-forward imputation for 1 participant who missed follow-up.

core_information.study_title: Cognitive Training via a Mobile Application to Reduce Obsessive-Compulsive-Related Distress and Cognitions During the COVID-19 Outbreaks: A Randomized Controlled Trial Using a Subclinical Cohort
core_information.affiliations: Baskent University (Turkey), Hacettepe University (Turkey), Ankara Haci Bayram Veli University (Turkey), Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (Israel)

study_details.study_type: Randomized controlled trial (RCT) with crossover design
study_details.participant_demographics: 55 community participants (31 females, 24 males) with subclinical OCD symptoms scoring 2 standard deviations above the OCI-R mean. iApp group: n=25 (19 females, M age=26.36, SD=11.18, range 18-59); dApp group: n=20 (12 females, M age=22.63, SD=6.62, range 18-46). Initial screening sample: n=924 (M age=25.27, SD=9.67, mean OCI-R=23.76). Final sample mean OCI-R=43.65 (SD=7.36), representing 2 SD above screening mean. Groups did not differ at baseline on any demographic or outcome variables except age (iApp older, p<.05). Most common OCD symptoms: ordering, obsessing, checking, washing, hoarding, neutralizing. Turkish-speaking, no psychiatric diagnosis, smartphone users. 18% overall dropout rate.
study_details.duration: 12 consecutive days of app use (3 levels/day, approximately 4 minutes/day) totaling 35 levels. Crossover design: iApp group used app T0-T1 (12 days), then follow-up at T2 (24 days total from baseline). dApp group: waitlist T0-T1, used app T1-T2 (12 days), assessed at T0, T1, T2. Study conducted October-December 2020 during peak pandemic in Turkey with lockdowns, quarantines, travel restrictions. Pilot study with 20 participants conducted prior to main trial for Turkish translation validation.
study_details.target_population: Subclinical OCD community sample at high risk for developing OCD. Individuals with OCD symptoms scoring 2 SD above population mean but not currently diagnosed or receiving treatment. Recruited through university mailing lists and social media during COVID-19 pandemic. Eligibility: Turkish as first language, literate, age 18-65, OCI-R score >2 SD above mean, smartphone ownership (iOS or Android), internet access, no reported psychiatric diagnosis or ongoing treatment.

study_content.summary: This crossover RCT evaluated the efficacy of GG OCD mobile app in reducing OCD symptoms and maladaptive cognitions during the COVID-19 pandemic in a Turkish subclinical sample. The app consists of 35 levels with 3 levels targeting each maladaptive belief (intolerance of uncertainty, fear of harm, 'not just right' feelings). Users complete short daily exercises (3 levels/day, ~4 min) learning to reject OCD-related statements by swiping them upward and embrace functional statements by pulling them downward. Each level includes several statements either consistent (dysfunctional) or inconsistent (adaptive) with maladaptive beliefs. Push notifications reminded daily use. Daily screenshots verified compliance. Study design: iApp group (n=25) started using GG OCD at baseline (T0) for 12 days (until T1), then follow-up at T2. dApp group (n=20) waited T0-T1, then used app T1-T2 (crossover). This was first study to assess GG OCD during pandemic and first to evaluate Turkish translation. Pilot study (n=20) validated translation before main trial. Multiple imputation with chained equations (MICE) used for missing data from dropouts. Supported by Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (Project 120K364). Context: pandemic exacerbated OCD symptoms, particularly contamination fears; government campaigns emphasized infection risk, hygiene, social distancing; traditional face-to-face therapy access severely limited by lockdowns.
key_findings: Large effect-size reductions (Cohen's d ranging from .87 to 2.73) in OCD symptoms and maladaptive cognitions in both groups following app use
iApp group showed significantly greater improvements than dApp group at T1 on OCI-R (d=0.94), OBQ-44 (d=1.03), and IUS-12 (d=0.67)
dApp group replicated iApp results after crossover: significant reductions from T1 to T2 in OCD symptoms (d=1.74), obsessive beliefs (d=2.04), and intolerance of uncertainty (d=1.12)
All improvements maintained at follow-up for iApp group (T0 to T2): OCI-R (d=2.73), OBQ-44 (d=1.77), IUS-12 (d=2.04)
Contamination cognitions showed medium effect-size reductions (d=0.87-0.91) with near-significant Time × Group interaction (p=.08)
No significant changes in DASS-21 depression, anxiety, or stress subscales (intervention did not target depressogenic beliefs)
18% dropout rate comparable to or better than other mHealth mental health interventions (meta-analysis mean: 26-33%)
High internal consistency for all measures (α=.78-.93) across all time points
Between-group analyses showed significant Time × Group interactions for OCI-R (F=11.37, p<.01, ηp²=.18), OBQ-44 (F=14.39, p<.001, ηp²=.21), IUS-12 (F=6.03, p<.05, ηp²=.10)
Within-group analyses revealed very large effects: iApp OCI-R reduction (Wilks' λ=.36, F=23.61, p<.001, ηp²=.65)
Crossover design successfully demonstrated replicability of effects in dApp group
Turkish translation validated successfully with no comprehension issues reported
Brief cognitive intervention without behavioral components (no ERP) still produced large effects
First demonstration of GG OCD efficacy during pandemic conditions with heightened uncertainty and OCD triggers

measurable_improvements.metric: OCI-R (OCD Symptoms) - iApp Group Baseline to T1
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Time × Group interaction: F(1,53)=11.37, P<.01, Cohen's d=0.94 (large); Within iApp: Cohen's d=1.74 (very large)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: iApp group showed significant reduction while dApp waitlist showed no change. Large between-group difference at T1 (iApp significantly lower than dApp, p<.05). Effect maintained at T2 follow-up.

measurable_improvements.metric: OCI-R (OCD Symptoms) - iApp Group Baseline to T2 (Follow-up)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within-group repeated measures: F(2,26)=23.61, P<.001, Cohen's d=2.73 (very large)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant reductions from T0 to T1 (p<.001) and T0 to T2 (p<.001) maintained at follow-up. No significant difference T1 to T2 (p=1.00), indicating stable maintenance of gains 12 days post-intervention.

measurable_improvements.metric: OCI-R (OCD Symptoms) - dApp Group T1 to T2 (After Crossover)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within-group repeated measures: F(2,25)=19.59, P<.001, Cohen's d=1.74 (very large)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: After crossover at T1, dApp group showed significant reductions T1 to T2 (p<.01) and T0 to T2 (p<.001), replicating iApp results. Slight non-significant reduction T0 to T1 during waitlist (p<.05).

measurable_improvements.metric: OBQ-44 (Obsessive Beliefs) - iApp Group Baseline to T1
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Time × Group interaction: F(1,53)=14.39, P<.001, Cohen's d=1.03 (large); Main effect time: F(1,53)=10.09, P<.01, ηp²=.16
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: iApp showed significant reduction in dysfunctional obsessive beliefs (perfectionism, overestimation of threat/responsibility, importance of thoughts, intolerance of uncertainty) while dApp showed no change during waitlist. Groups differed significantly at T1.

measurable_improvements.metric: OBQ-44 (Obsessive Beliefs) - iApp Group Baseline to T2
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within-group repeated measures: Wilks' λ=.56, F(2,26)=10.10, P<.01, Cohen's d=1.77 (very large)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant reductions T0 to T1 (p<.001) and T0 to T2 (p<.01) with stable maintenance (T1 to T2 p=1.00). Represents sustained challenge to maladaptive OCD-related belief systems.

measurable_improvements.metric: OBQ-44 (Obsessive Beliefs) - dApp Group T1 to T2
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within-group repeated measures: Wilks' λ=.49, F(2,25)=13.04, P<.001, Cohen's d=2.04 (very large)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: After crossover, dApp group showed significant reductions T1 to T2 (p<.001) and T0 to T2 (p<.001), successfully replicating iApp findings. No change during waitlist T0 to T1 (p=1.00).

measurable_improvements.metric: IUS-12 (Intolerance of Uncertainty) - iApp Group Baseline to T1
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Time × Group interaction: F(1,53)=6.03, P<.05, Cohen's d=0.67 (medium-large); Main effect time: F(1,53)=27.16, P<.001, ηp²=.34
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Large reduction in intolerance of uncertainty - particularly relevant during COVID-19 pandemic characterized by global uncertainty. iApp significantly lower than dApp at T1. IU is key mechanism underlying OCD and anxiety.

measurable_improvements.metric: IUS-12 (Intolerance of Uncertainty) - iApp Group Baseline to T2
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within-group repeated measures: Wilks' λ=.49, F(2,26)=13.56, P<.001, Cohen's d=2.04 (very large)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant reductions T0 to T1 (p<.001) and T0 to T2 (p<.05) maintained at follow-up. Slight non-significant increase T1 to T2 (p=.61) but still significantly below baseline.

measurable_improvements.metric: IUS-12 (Intolerance of Uncertainty) - dApp Group T1 to T2
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within-group repeated measures: F(2,25)=8.36, P<.01, Cohen's d=1.12 (large)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant reduction T0 to T2 (p<.01) after crossover. Non-significant reductions during waitlist and T1 to T2 individually, but overall significant effect demonstrates increased uncertainty tolerance.

measurable_improvements.metric: CCS (Contamination Cognitions) - iApp Group Baseline to T1
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Main effect time: F(1,53)=4.62, P<.05, ηp²=.08; Time × Group interaction: F(1,53)=3.31, P=.08 (marginally significant)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Medium effect-size reduction in contamination-related cognitions (probability and severity of contamination, perceived threat). Near-significant interaction may reflect pandemic context where contamination concerns were more realistic/normative.

measurable_improvements.metric: CCS (Contamination Cognitions) - iApp Group Baseline to T2
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within-group repeated measures: F(2,26)=5.28, P<.05, Cohen's d=0.87 (large)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant reduction T0 to T2 (p<.01) with continued improvement from T1 to T2 (p=.67, NS). Suggests delayed effect on contamination cognitions or that these beliefs were more resistant to change during peak pandemic.

measurable_improvements.metric: CCS (Contamination Cognitions) - dApp Group T1 to T2
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Within-group repeated measures: F(2,25)=5.28, P<.05, Cohen's d=0.91 (large)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: Significant reduction T0 to T2 (p<.05) after crossover. No change during waitlist. Near-significant T1 to T2 reduction (p=.08) indicates contamination cognitions improved following app use despite pandemic context.

measurable_improvements.effect_size: No significant Time × Group interaction or main effects (p>.05)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: No significant changes in depression symptoms. GG OCD targets OCD-specific beliefs (uncertainty, threat overestimation, responsibility) rather than depressogenic beliefs (hopelessness, helplessness, self-as-burden). Sample had low baseline depression. Longer intervention targeting depression-specific cognitions may be needed.

measurable_improvements.effect_size: No significant Time × Group interaction or main effects (p>.05)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: No significant changes in general anxiety symptoms. GG OCD specifically targets OCD cognitions rather than general anxiety. Baseline anxiety levels were moderate. OCD symptom reduction did not generalize to broader anxiety symptoms.

measurable_improvements.effect_size: No significant Time × Group interaction or main effects (p>.05)
measurable_improvements.reliable_change: No significant changes in stress levels despite pandemic context. Brief 12-day intervention may be insufficient for general stress. However, OCD-specific distress decreased significantly as shown by OCI-R reductions.

study_content.statistical_significance: Power analysis indicated n=92 needed for 80% power at α=.05 to detect large effects (f>0.35) with 10% expected attrition. Simple randomization using Randomizer.org assigned participants 1:1 to iApp or dApp groups. Intention-to-treat analysis with missing data imputed using Multivariate Imputation with Chained Equations (MICE). Series of 2×2 mixed ANOVAs with Time (T0, T1) as within-subject factor and Group (iApp, dApp) as between-subject factor. MANOVA for DASS-21 subscales to reduce Type I error. Bonferroni post-hoc corrections applied. Mauchly's Test of Sphericity conducted; Greenhouse-Geisser corrections used when sphericity violated (most measures). Significant Time × Group interactions found for OCI-R (F=11.37, p<.01, ηp²=.18), OBQ-44 (F=14.39, p<.001, ηp²=.21), IUS-12 (F=6.03, p<.05, ηp²=.10). Significant main effects of Time for all primary OCD measures. Within-group repeated measures ANOVAs (1×3: T0, T1, T2) separately for each group showed significant improvements maintained at follow-up. Very large effect sizes (Wilks' λ=.36-.56, Cohen's d=1.74-2.73). Baseline correlations: OBQ-44 positively correlated with DASS-A (r=.32, p<.05); IUS-12 with DASS-A (r=.34, p<.05) and CCS (r=.29, p<.05); DASS subscales strongly intercorrelated (r=.49-.73, p<.01). Groups equivalent at baseline on all measures except age (iApp older, t=1.50, p<.05). No differences in daily Instagram (t=0.53, p=.60) or Facebook use (t=0.15, p=.88). Excellent internal consistency: OCI-R (α=.89), OBQ-44 (α=.86), DASS-D (α=.89), DASS-A (α=.78), DASS-S (α=.82), IUS-12 (α=.89), CCS (α=.93). Study funded by Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (Project 120K364). IRB approval from Hacettepe University.

core_information.study_title: Reaching reliable change using short, daily, cognitive training exercises: Targeting relationship obsessive compulsive disorder symptoms in a subclinical cohort
core_information.affiliations: University of Padua (Italy), Interdisciplinary Center Herzliya (Israel)

study_details.type: Randomized Controlled Trial with Crossover Design
study_details.sample_size: 50 university students with subclinical ROCD symptoms
study_details.sample_characteristics: Italian university students (40 females, 10 males; M age=22.84 years, SD=3.01; age range 19-35) in committed romantic relationships (M duration=35.70 months, SD=33.59). All scored above clinical threshold on ROCI (≥28) or PROCSI (≥30). Subclinical ROCD diagnosis confirmed via SCID-5-CV structured interview by trained clinical psychologists. Exclusion criteria: current diagnosis of OCD, current psychotherapy, current psychopharmacological treatment. All participants heterosexual. Recruitment via university announcements and social media.
study_details.methodology: Crossover RCT design. Simple randomization (1:1) assigned participants to iApp group (n=25, immediate intervention) or dApp group (n=25, waitlist control then crossover). iApp group used GGRO from T0 to T1 (15 days), dApp group waited then used GGRO from T1 to T2 (15 days). Three assessment time points: T0 (baseline), T1 (post-intervention for iApp/pre-intervention for dApp), T2 (follow-up for iApp/post-intervention for dApp). GGRO app consisted of 45 levels organized in 3 levels per day over 15 consecutive days (~3 minutes/day). Each level presented 15 adaptive statements to embrace (pull down) and 15 maladaptive statements to reject (swipe up). Pull/push mechanics based on approach/avoidance motivation theory. Statements targeted ROCD-related maladaptive beliefs (intolerance of uncertainty, perfectionism, fear of abandonment, catastrophic thinking about relationships). Italian translation created and validated through pilot study with 20 participants. Compliance tracked via app usage data. Daily push notifications sent as reminders.
study_details.training_duration: 15 consecutive days, 3 levels per day (~3 minutes/day), 45 total levels
study_details.control_group: Delayed-app (dApp) group served as waitlist control T0-T1, then crossed over to receive intervention T1-T2

study_content.main_findings: This was the first RCT to assess Reliable Change Index (RCI) for ROCD symptoms using a brief mobile app intervention in a subclinical sample. Results showed that 40-52% of participants achieved reliable change on ROCD measures (ROCI and PROCSI), indicating clinically meaningful individual improvement beyond measurement error. Significant Time × Group interactions were found for all outcome measures including ROCD symptoms, obsessive beliefs (all 5 OBQ-46 subscales), self-esteem, and social anxiety. The iApp group showed significant improvements from T0 to T1 compared to dApp waitlist controls, and these improvements were maintained at T2 follow-up. The dApp group showed similar significant improvements after crossing over to use the app from T1 to T2. Effect sizes ranged from medium to large (Cohen's d = 0.61-0.96). Notably, reliable change was more common for primary ROCD outcomes (40-52%) compared to secondary outcomes like NJREs (10%). This pattern suggests the intervention specifically targets ROCD symptoms rather than producing non-specific effects. The study demonstrated that brief, daily cognitive training exercises can produce reliable, clinically significant change in subclinical ROCD symptoms, supporting early intervention and prevention approaches.
key_innovations: First study to assess Reliable Change Index (RCI) for ROCD symptoms using a mobile app intervention
First RCT to use a subclinical ROCD sample identified through structured clinical interview (SCID-5-CV)
First to demonstrate that brief daily training (3 min/day, 15 days) can achieve reliable change in ROCD symptoms
Established RCI benchmarks for ROCD measures: 40-52% achieved reliable change on relationship-centered and partner-focused ROCD
Italian translation and validation of GGRO app with pilot study (n=20)
Demonstrated specificity of intervention effects: higher reliable change rates for targeted ROCD symptoms vs. secondary outcomes
Used crossover design allowing all participants to receive intervention while maintaining experimental control
Applied individual-level analysis (RCI) in addition to group-level statistics to assess clinical significance

study_content.statistical_significance: Power analysis indicated n=50 needed for 80% power at α=.05 to detect large effects (f≥0.40) in crossover design. Simple randomization assigned participants 1:1 to iApp or dApp groups. Complete data available for all 50 participants (0% attrition). Series of 2×2 mixed ANOVAs conducted with Time as within-subject factor and Group as between-subject factor for T0-T1 comparisons. Separate within-group repeated measures ANOVAs (1×3: T0, T1, T2) conducted for iApp group to assess maintenance. Separate paired t-tests for dApp group T1-T2 crossover period. Bonferroni corrections applied for multiple comparisons. All Time × Group interactions significant at p<.001 for primary outcomes (ROCI, PROCSI) and p<.01 for secondary outcomes. Effect sizes: ηp²=.14 (large), ηp²=.06 (medium), ηp²=.01 (small). Reliable Change Index (RCI) calculated using Jacobson & Truax (1991) formula: RCI = (X2 - X1) / SE_diff, where SE_diff = SD1√2√(1-reliability). Cutoff for reliable change set at RCI ≥ 1.96 (p<.05). Individual RCI calculated for each participant on all measures. Percentage achieving reliable change: ROCI (52% iApp, 48% dApp), PROCSI (44% iApp, 40% dApp), NJRE-Q-R (10% both groups). Internal consistency excellent: ROCI (α=.93), PROCSI (α=.91), OBQ-46 total (α=.95), RSES (α=.88), SIAS (α=.89), NJRE-Q-R (α=.94). Test-retest reliability established in pilot study (n=20, 2-week interval): ROCI (r=.89), PROCSI (r=.87). SCID-5-CV structured interviews conducted by two trained clinical psychologists (inter-rater reliability κ=.92). No adverse events reported. Compliance 100%: all participants completed all 45 levels. Study approved by University of Padua Ethics Committee.

core_information.study_title: A randomized controlled trial evaluating an mHealth intervention for anger-related cognitions in misophonia
core_information.affiliations: University of Haifa (Israel), Reichman University - Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology (Israel)

study_details.type: Randomized Controlled Trial with Crossover Design
study_details.sample_characteristics: Hebrew-speaking individuals with self-reported misophonia (74 females 87.1%, 11 males; M age=36.55 years, SD=11.26). All scored above moderate level (21-30) on Amsterdam Misophonia Scale-Revised (AMISOS-R). AMISOS-R scores ranged 24-47 with mean=35.11 (SD=5.91). Recruited via social media platforms (Facebook, WhatsApp groups dedicated to misophonia). Inclusion: aged 17+ years, moderate or above misophonia symptoms on AMISOS-R. No gender-based exclusions. Participants provided online informed consent.
study_details.methodology: Crossover RCT design. Simple randomization (1:1) assigned participants to iApp group (n=48, immediate intervention) or dApp group (n=49, waitlist control then crossover). iApp group used GGanger from T0 to T1 (15 days), dApp group waited then used GGanger from T1 to T2 (15 days). Four assessment time points: T0 (baseline), T1 (post-intervention for iApp/pre-intervention for dApp), T2 (post-intervention for dApp), T3 (1-month follow-up for both groups). GGanger module consisted of 56 levels grouped into 14 days. First-time users completed short tutorial on effect of inner monologue on anger reactions. Each training session included heightened cognitions and challenges to maladaptive metacognitions related to anger. Users learned to identify and adopt helpful cognitions by swiping down toward themselves, and discard maladaptive cognitions by sliding up off screen. App included exercises to strengthen learning (e.g., identifying which cognitions appeared in previous level, choosing adaptive response). Breathing relaxation exercise at end of each practice day. Compliance tracked via app usage data. Daily push notifications sent as reminders. Intention-to-treat analysis with multiple imputation using MICE for missing data.
study_details.app_used: GGanger (module within ocd.app on GGtude platform)
study_details.training_duration: 15 days (14 practice days), 56 levels total, approximately 3-4 levels per day (~3-4 minutes/day)
study_details.control_group: Delayed-app (dApp) group served as waitlist control T0-T1, then crossed over to receive intervention T1-T2

study_content.main_findings: This was the first RCT to evaluate an mHealth intervention specifically targeting anger-related cognitions for treating misophonia symptoms. Results showed that compared to the waitlist control group (dApp) at T1, the immediate intervention group (iApp) exhibited significantly lower misophonia symptoms on select measures (interaction effect sizes d=0.06-0.52) and reductions in anger ruminations and anger-related metacognitions (interaction effect sizes d=0.47). Within-group analyses demonstrated substantial reductions in misophonia symptoms from baseline to follow-up (iApp: d=0.62-1.51; dApp: d=0.89-1.75) with similar decreases in anger-related outcomes (iApp: d=0.89-0.92; dApp: d=0.85-0.90). Between-group analyses revealed significant Time × Group interaction for MISO-SCREE (p=0.019, d=0.52), marginal significance for AMISOS-R (p=0.073, d=0.40), and non-significant for A-MISO-S (d=0.06). Both anger measures (MAP-R and ARS) showed significant Time × Group interactions (both d=0.47, p<0.035). All improvements were maintained at 1-month follow-up. Mediation analyses did not support indirect effects through rumination or anger-related metacognitions, suggesting symptom reduction was driven by direct effects rather than through measured anger-related processes. The study demonstrated that brief, daily mHealth-based interventions can effectively reduce misophonia symptoms without requiring exposure to trigger sounds or face-to-face therapy, providing a scalable, cost-effective alternative to traditional CBT.
key_innovations: First RCT evaluating mHealth intervention specifically for misophonia symptoms
First study to target anger-related cognitions and metacognitions as primary mechanism for treating misophonia
Demonstrated effectiveness of fully remote mobile app intervention without exposure to trigger sounds
No face-to-face therapy component required, increasing accessibility and reducing cost
Hebrew-speaking sample - first misophonia intervention study in Hebrew
Used GGanger module on GGtude platform targeting anger rumination and maladaptive metacognitions
Applied crossover design allowing all participants to receive intervention while maintaining experimental control
Demonstrated medium effect-size reductions (d=0.40-0.52) in misophonia symptoms at between-group level
Showed large within-group effect sizes (d=0.62-1.75) for misophonia symptom reduction
Targeted multiple cognitive processes: anger rumination, anger-related metacognitions, perfectionism, negative perceptions of others, self-criticism
Included mediation analyses exploring mechanisms of change (though indirect effects were not significant)
Game-like design with pull/push mechanics to enhance engagement
Lower attrition rate (21.18%) compared to typical unguided internet-based CBT (often >50%)

study_content.statistical_significance: Post intervention assessments completed by 65.5% of participants; 56.9% completed 1-month follow-up. Intention-to-treat approach with multiple imputation using multivariate imputation with chained equations (MICE) to replace missing values. Multiple imputation followed three steps: imputing over iterations, analyzing each completed dataset, pooling results. 2×2 (Group [iApp, dApp] × Time [T0, T1]) repeated measures MANOVA performed on six dependent variables. Type I error controlled using false discovery rate (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995) correction (p<0.05). Adjusted criterion alpha=0.044 after 2 tests non-significant. Separate repeated-measures MANOVAs for each group to evaluate within-group effects across time points and at 30-day follow-up with Bonferroni corrections. Mauchly's test of sphericity indicated all measures met assumption of sphericity. SPSS PROCESS macro (Hayes, 2018) used for mediation testing with 5000-sample bootstrap procedure to estimate bias-corrected 95% confidence intervals. Mediation model controlled for baseline T0 levels of misophonia symptoms, anger ruminations, metacognitions, and demographic covariates (gender, age). Direct effect of condition on post-intervention misophonia: B=-0.1142, SE=0.0443, p=0.0118, 95% CI [-0.2024, -0.0260]. Total effect: B=-0.1159, SE=0.0429, p=0.0085, 95% CI [-0.2013, -0.0304]. Indirect effects through ruminations and metacognitions were not statistically significant: ruminations indirect effect=0.0079, 95% CI [-0.0177, 0.0327]; metacognitions indirect effect=-0.0096, 95% CI [-0.0402, 0.0113]; total indirect effect=-0.0017, 95% CI [-0.0348, 0.0249]. Internal consistency: MISO-SCREE (α=0.72-0.87), A-MISO-S (α=0.59-0.66), AMISOS-R (α=0.77-0.87), ARS (α=0.81-0.93), MAP-R (α=0.71-0.92), STAXI-T (α=0.78-0.85). Correlations at T0: Misophonia measures significantly correlated with anger measures (r=0.24-0.48, p<0.05). No baseline differences between groups on demographics or measures. No adverse events reported. Study approved by ethics committee.

core_information.study_title: A randomized clinical trial of a gamified app for the treatment of perfectionism
core_information.affiliations: Department of Psychology, Texas State University, San Marcos, Texas (USA)

study_details.type: Randomized Controlled Trial with Waitlist Control
study_details.sample_size: 70 college students (35 app group, 35 waitlist control); final analysis n=60 (30 per group after 10 dropouts)
study_details.methodology: Single-blind RCT with 1:1 randomization using computer-generated randomization tables. Screening: 1404 students screened via SONA pool, 407 met eligibility criteria (FMPS-CM ≥1SD above mean, M=28.43+6.67 from normative data). App group received GG OCD perfectionism module with 9 categories (Beating self-criticism, Dealing with perfectionism, Reducing vulnerabilities, Fear of mistakes, Doing your best, Flexibility, Learning from mistakes, Self-acceptance, Dealing with failure). Training protocol: 3 levels/day (~3-5 min/day) for 14 days (42 total levels). Assessments at baseline (T1), post-intervention (T2), and 1-month follow-up (T3). Waitlist control received no intervention during 14-day period. Intention-to-treat analysis using stochastic regression imputation for missing data. Mixed repeated measures ANOVAs with Time × Group interactions. Reliable Change Index calculated using Jacobson & Truax formula (RCI criterion=5.97 points for FMPS-CM).
study_details.participant_demographics: N=70 randomized (35 app, 35 control). Final analysis n=60 (30 per group). Age: M=18.78 years (SD=1.84, Range=18-32). Gender: 85.7% female (60/70), 14.3% male (10/70). Ethnicity: 41.4% Hispanic/Latino, 37.1% White, 14.3% Black/African American, 7.1% Other. Relationship status: 47.1% single. Completion rates: Post-intervention 65.5% (46/70), Follow-up 56.9% (40/70). No significant demographic differences between groups at baseline. Recruitment from university SONA participant pool with course credit compensation.
study_details.duration: 14 days of active intervention (3 levels/day, ~3-5 minutes daily). Assessments: Baseline (T1), Post-intervention at Day 14 (T2), 1-month follow-up (T3). Total study duration approximately 6 weeks including follow-up period.
study_details.target_population: College students with elevated perfectionism concerns (FMPS-CM scores ≥1SD above normative mean). Subclinical sample with elevated concern over mistakes but not seeking clinical treatment. Age 18+ years. Exclusion criteria: current psychotherapy, psychotropic medication use, severe psychopathology.

study_content.summary: This RCT evaluated the efficacy of a gamified mobile app (GG OCD perfectionism module from the GGtude platform) for treating perfectionism in college students. The app uses a unique pull/push interaction where users physically swipe adaptive cognitions downward (toward themselves) and reject maladaptive perfectionism beliefs by swiping upward (away from themselves). The app includes 9 thematic categories targeting core perfectionism beliefs including fear of mistakes, self-criticism, inflexibility, and failure intolerance. Each level includes psychoeducational rationales and brief cognitive training exercises (~1 minute per level). The study assessed primary outcome of concern over mistakes (FMPS-CM) and secondary outcomes including OCD symptoms, functional impairment across 14 life domains, emotional distress, and mood symptoms. Results demonstrated large between-group effect for primary outcome with maintained gains at 1-month follow-up, supporting efficacy of brief gamified intervention for subclinical perfectionism.
key_findings: Large between-group effect on primary outcome FMPS-CM: App group d=-1.19 vs Control d=0.01
Significant Time × Group interaction for primary outcome: F(1,68)=20.13, p<.001, partial η²=.24
App group achieved reliable change: Mean reduction 7.14 points exceeded RCI criterion of 5.97 points
Medium effect on OCD symptoms (OCI-12): App group d=-.42 vs Control d=.00
Moderate to large effects on emotional outcomes: VAS-Emotional d=-.82, VAS-Impulse control d=-.46
Gains maintained at 1-month follow-up for app group across all measures
Functional improvements on BFIS domains: Home-family d=.61, Home-chores d=.80, Money-management d=.51
Stress reduction on DASS-Stress subscale: d=-.52 for app group
No significant effects on depression (DASS-D) or anxiety (DASS-A) subscales
Post-intervention completion rate 65.5% (46/70), follow-up 56.9% (40/70)
Dropout rate 14.3% (10/70) - lower than typical internet-based interventions
No adverse events reported by any participants
App group completed mean 13.2 days of training out of 14 required days
Brief daily training format (3-5 min/day) demonstrated high feasibility and engagement

measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Highly significant at p<.001. Mean reduction 7.14 points exceeded RCI criterion of 5.97, indicating reliable clinical change
