measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Significant at p=.018. Improvement in financial management

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Small-medium between-group: d=.26 (app improvement) vs d=-.02 (control). Time × Group: F(1,68)=2.45, p=.122, partial η²=.03
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Not significant at p=.122. Trend toward improvement in social functioning

measurable_improvements.metric: BFIS Overall Functional Impairment (Total score across 14 domains)
measurable_improvements.result: App group showed improvements across multiple BFIS domains with strongest effects in home-chores (d=.80), home-family (d=.61), and money management (d=.51)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Multiple medium to large effects across functional domains. Perfectionism intervention showed cross-domain functional benefits
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Significant improvements in 3 of 14 BFIS domains (Home-family p=.004, Home-chores p=.001, Money-management p=.018)

study_content.statistical_significance: Mixed repeated measures ANOVAs conducted with Time (T1, T2, T3) as within-subjects factor and Group (App, Control) as between-subjects factor. Primary analysis focused on Time × Group interactions. Intention-to-treat analysis with stochastic regression imputation for missing data. Effect sizes calculated using Cohen's d for within-group changes and between-group differences. Reliable Change Index (RCI) calculated using Jacobson & Truax (1991) formula: RCI = (X2 - X1) / Sdiff, where Sdiff = √(2(SE)²) and SE = SD1√(1-rxx). RCI criterion for FMPS-CM = 5.97 points based on test-retest reliability rxx=.88 and baseline SD=5.67. Internal consistency: FMPS-CM α=.89, OCI-12 α=.87, DASS-21 α=.94, BFIS α=.95. Power analysis indicated n=60 provided 80% power to detect medium effect size (f=.25) at α=.05 for Time × Group interaction.

core_information.study_title: Evaluating the combined effects of mobile computerized CBT and post-learning oscillatory modulation on self-esteem: a randomized controlled trial
core_information.affiliations: The Dina Recanati School of Medicine, Reichman University, Herzliya (Israel); Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology, Reichman University, Herzliya (Israel); Department of Psychology, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer Sheva (Israel); Department of Psychology, Palo Alto University, Palo Alto, CA (USA)

study_details.type: Six-Month Longitudinal Randomized Controlled Trial with Three Arms
study_details.sample_size: 85 young adults with low self-esteem (RSES<16). Screened 179 participants via Qualtrics, 85 enrolled. Three groups: Theta group (n=31: 20F, 11M), Beta group (n=29: 17F, 12M), GGSE only control group (n=25: 15F, 10M)
study_details.methodology: Three-arm RCT comparing: (1) GGSE + theta audio-visual entrainment (AVE) with Cranio-Electro Stimulation (CES), (2) GGSE + beta AVE+CES (active control), and (3) GGSE only (control). Random allocation to groups. Training protocol: GGSE app 5 days/week for 3 weeks (15 total days, ~5 min/day), followed immediately by AVE+CES device (20 min/day) in theta (5.5 Hz) or beta (15 Hz) mode for stimulation groups. DAVID DELIGHT PRO device used for AVE+CES with rhythmic flashing lights, pulsing tones, and mild electrical currents via earlobe electrodes. Assessments at baseline (T0), 21 days post-baseline (T1, post-intervention), 42 days post-baseline (T2, 1-month follow-up), and 6 months post-baseline (T3). Participants conducted intervention at home with daily monitoring via Zoom/phone. Mixed repeated measures ANOVAs with Group × Time interactions. Missing data handled with MICE (multivariate imputation by chained equations). Reliable Change Index (RCI) calculated using Jacobson & Truax formula to assess clinically meaningful individual change. Intention-to-treat analysis.
study_details.participant_demographics: N=85 young adults (52 females, 61.2%; mean age 23.3 years, SD 3.3, range 18-37) with low self-esteem (RSES<16). Recruited from campus communities and nearby areas. Exclusion criteria: hearing problems, neurological/psychiatric problems, learning disabilities/ADD, regular drug use, pacemaker, epilepsy, regular alcohol use, head injuries/tumor/stroke, ear piercing, earlobe skin injuries. No significant differences between groups at baseline on age, gender, or any outcome measures. Monetary compensation of 400 NIS provided. All participants provided informed consent.
study_details.duration: 3 weeks active intervention (5 days/week excluding Fridays/Saturdays, 15 total days). GGSE training ~5 min/day. AVE+CES stimulation 20 min/day (for theta and beta groups). Longitudinal follow-up: Assessments at baseline (T0), 21 days (T1, post-intervention), 42 days (T2, 1-month follow-up), and 6 months (T3). Participants did NOT use app after initial 3-week intervention period. Total study duration: 6 months.
study_details.target_population: Young adults (ages 18-37) with low self-esteem (RSES<16). Non-clinical sample recruited from university campus communities and nearby areas. Participants with low self-esteem who may not seek clinical treatment but are at increased vulnerability for psychopathology. Exclusion of individuals with serious medical/psychiatric conditions or factors incompatible with AVE+CES device.

study_content.summary: This 6-month longitudinal RCT investigated whether combining mobile computerized CBT (GGSE module of GGtude platform) with post-training brain oscillatory modulation could enhance and prolong treatment effects for low self-esteem. The study tested the hypothesis that theta rhythm entrainment following daily CBT training would optimize memory consolidation and stabilize therapeutic gains. GGSE targets 11 maladaptive beliefs related to low self-esteem (e.g., perfectionism, self-criticism, social comparison tendencies) using brief gamified interactions with pull/push mechanics. The study included sophisticated neuromodulation using audio-visual entrainment (AVE) combined with cranial electro-stimulation (CES) at theta (5.5 Hz) or beta (15 Hz) frequencies. Contrary to the primary hypothesis, results showed no synergistic benefit of theta modulation - all three groups (theta, beta active control, and GGSE-only) demonstrated similar medium-to-large improvements in self-esteem that persisted for 6 months. This represents the longest follow-up assessment of GGtude platform efficacy to date and the first RCT comparing GGSE with active control groups, providing strong evidence for long-term maintenance of CBT-based self-esteem improvements via mobile apps.
key_findings: No synergistic effect of theta oscillatory modulation - all three groups showed equivalent improvements
Significant main effect of Time on self-esteem: F(3,214)=25.18, p<.001, partial η²=.23
No significant Group × Time interaction: F(5,214)=0.89, p=.491, partial η²=.02
No main effect of Group: F(2,82)=0.25, p=.778, partial η²=.01
Medium to large effect sizes maintained across 6 months for all groups
Theta group improvements: d=0.70 (baseline to post), d=0.55 (baseline to 1-month), d=0.76 (baseline to 6-month)
Beta group improvements: d=0.67 (baseline to post), d=0.88 (baseline to 1-month), d=0.67 (baseline to 6-month)
GGSE only improvements: d=0.56 (baseline to post), d=0.56 (baseline to 1-month), d=0.59 (baseline to 6-month)
20% of all participants achieved reliable clinical change (RCI) at 6 months: Theta 22.6% (7 participants), Beta 13.8% (4 participants), GGSE only 24% (6 participants)
No significant differences between groups in RCI proportions: χ²=1.08, p=.58
All groups showed significant improvements from baseline to all subsequent time points (p<.01)
Improvements maintained at 1-month and 6-month follow-ups with no decline
First study demonstrating 6-month maintenance of GGtude platform effects
First RCT comparing GGSE module specifically (not other GGtude modules) with active controls
Secondary outcomes also improved significantly over time: DAS, MPS, SCS, INCOM, DASS, SIAS
No Group × Time interactions for any secondary outcomes (all p>.05)
SIAS showed main effect of Group: F(2,82)=3.25, p=.044, but no interaction with time
AVE+CES with theta frequency did not enhance consolidation compared to beta or no stimulation
Supports long-term efficacy of brief, gamified, digital CBT for self-esteem improvement
Home-based intervention with daily monitoring proved feasible and effective
GGSE app includes 46 training levels targeting 11 maladaptive beliefs/metacognitions
Brief daily training (5 min) sufficient for sustained improvements over 6 months

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Baseline to Post: d=0.70, t=4.32, p<.001. Baseline to 1-month: d=0.55, t=3.77, p<.001. Baseline to 6-month: d=0.76, t=4.08, p<.001
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Highly significant improvements at all time points. All comparisons p<.01. Gains maintained across 6 months.

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Baseline to Post: d=0.67, t=4.00, p<.001. Baseline to 1-month: d=0.88, t=5.91, p<.001. Baseline to 6-month: d=0.67, t=3.45, p<.001
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Highly significant improvements at all time points. Beta group showed largest effect at 1-month follow-up (d=0.88).

measurable_improvements.metric: RSES Self-Esteem (Primary Outcome) - GGSE Only Group
measurable_improvements.effect_size: Baseline to Post: d=0.56, t=3.11, p=.004. Baseline to 1-month: d=0.56, t=3.46, p=.003. Baseline to 6-month: d=0.59, t=2.82, p=.006
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Significant improvements at all time points despite no brain stimulation. Medium effect sizes comparable to stimulation groups.

measurable_improvements.metric: Reliable Change Index (RCI) on RSES - Clinical Significance
measurable_improvements.result: Overall: 20% (17/85 participants) achieved reliable clinical change. Theta: 22.6% (7/31), Beta: 13.8% (4/29), GGSE only: 24% (6/25)
measurable_improvements.effect_size: RCI calculated using Jacobson & Truax formula with test-retest reliability and baseline SD. Threshold: 1.96 × SE of difference
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: No significant differences between groups in proportion achieving RCI: χ²=1.08, df=2, p=.58. One in five participants achieved clinically meaningful change.

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Main effect of Time: F(2.59,212.76)=24.62, p<.001, partial η²=.23. No Group × Time interaction: F(5.19,212.76)=1.29, p=.27
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Highly significant reduction in dysfunctional attitudes over time across all groups. Large effect size (partial η²=.23).

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Main effect of Time: F(2.69,220.64)=19.66, p<.001, partial η²=.19. No Group × Time interaction: F(5.38,220.64)=0.68, p=.649
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Highly significant reduction in perfectionism over time. Large effect size maintained at 6 months.

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Main effect of Time: F(2.70,221.72)=30.04, p<.001, partial η²=.27. No Group × Time interaction: F(5.41,221.72)=2.02, p=.071
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Highly significant increase in self-compassion. Largest effect size of all secondary outcomes (partial η²=.27).

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Main effect of Time: F(2.77,226.92)=23.19, p<.001, partial η²=.22. No Group × Time interaction: F(5.53,226.92)=0.51, p=.788
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Highly significant reduction in psychological distress across all groups. Large effect size (partial η²=.22).

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Main effect of Time: F(2.92,239.64)=11.96, p<.001, partial η²=.13. No Group × Time interaction: F(5.84,239.64)=1.21, p=.303
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Significant reduction in social comparison tendencies. Medium-large effect size.

measurable_improvements.effect_size: Main effect of Group: F(2,82)=3.25, p=.044, partial η²=.07. Main effect of Time: F(2.61,214.12)=13.12, p<.001, partial η²=.14. No Group × Time interaction: F(5.22,214.12)=1.73, p=.126
measurable_improvements.statistical_significance: Significant reduction in social anxiety over time. Theta group showed largest improvements. Only secondary outcome with significant group effect.

study_content.statistical_significance: Mixed repeated measures ANOVAs conducted using R version 4.4.0 with afex and emmeans packages. Group (Theta/Beta/GGSE only) as between-subjects factor and Time (T0, T1, T2, T3) as within-subjects factor. Primary analysis focused on Group × Time interactions and main effects. Missing data imputed using MICE package with multivariate imputation by chained equations. Baseline comparisons: one-way ANOVAs for continuous variables, Chi-square for categorical variables. Effect sizes: Partial eta-squared for ANOVAs, Cohen's d for pairwise comparisons. Reliable Change Index (RCI) calculated using Jacobson & Truax (1991) formula: RCI = (X2 - X1) / Sdiff, where Sdiff = √(2(SE)²) and SE = SD1√(1-rxx). Threshold for reliable change: 1.96 × SE. Internal consistency (Cronbach's α) excellent across all measures and time points: RSES α=.85-.89, MPS α=.73-.77, DASS α=.90-.94, SCS α=.79-.88, DAS α=.88-.91, INCOM α=.81-.87, SIAS α=.92-.94. Power analysis indicated adequate sample size. Chi-square test of independence for RCI group comparisons. All participants analyzed using intention-to-treat principles.

core_information.study_title: Promoting couples' resilience to relationship obsessive compulsive disorder (ROCD) symptoms using a CBT-based mobile application: A randomized controlled trial
core_information.affiliations: Baruch Ivcher School of Psychology, Reichman University, Herzliya (Israel); Stony Brook University, NY (USA); Department of Psychology, Palo Alto University, Palo Alto, CA (USA)

study_details.type: Randomized Controlled Trial with Waitlist Control - First Couples Intervention Study
study_details.sample_size: 103 heterosexual couples (206 individuals initially; 160 completed post-intervention, 128 completed follow-up). Experimental group: 49 couples assigned to GGRO app. Control group: 54 couples assigned to waitlist control. Overall dropout rate: 22.33% (23 couples). Age: M=26.15 years (SD=5.36, Range=18-51). Relationship duration: M=3.53 years (SD=2.91). 100% heterosexual couples.
study_details.methodology: Two-arm parallel RCT with random assignment of couples (not individuals) to GGRO app or waitlist control. Both partners in experimental couples used GGRO app concurrently for 15 days (3 min/day, 3 levels/day, 45 total levels across 5 categories: Dealing with doubts, Learning to trust, Self-acceptance, Building strong relationships, Secure relationships). Unique pull/push gamified mechanics: upward swipe rejects ROCD thoughts, downward swipe embraces adaptive beliefs. Novel resilience task methodology: at T2 (post-intervention), participants exposed to bogus triggering article titled 'Not Getting Butterflies When You See Your Partner Is a Major Red Flag' to test resilience to stressful ROCD-related content. Assessments at T1 (baseline), T2 (Day 15, post-intervention + resilience task), T3 (Day 45, 1-month follow-up). Primary outcomes: Relationship-Centered (ROCI) and Partner-Focused (PROCSI) ROCD symptoms, resilience task ROCD symptoms. Secondary outcomes: Relationship Catastrophizing (ReCats), OCD beliefs (OBQ-20), adult attachment (ECR-S), relationship satisfaction (RAS), sexual satisfaction (CSFQ-14), general distress (DASS-21), social anxiety (SIAS). Intention-to-treat analysis with Multivariate Imputation by Chained Equations (MICE) for missing data. Mixed 2×3×2 MANOVAs (Group × Time × Gender) with Bonferroni corrections. Per-protocol sensitivity analyses confirmed intention-to-treat findings.
study_details.participant_demographics: N=103 couples (206 individuals) randomized. Experimental group: 49 couples (98 individuals). Control group: 54 couples (108 individuals). Age: M=26.15 years (SD=5.36, Range=18-51 years). Relationship duration: M=3.53 years (SD=2.91). 100% heterosexual couples. All participants recruited through social media in Israel and provided informed consent. Inclusion criteria: adults in committed heterosexual relationships ≥1 year duration, Hebrew speakers, smartphone access. Exclusion criteria: current psychotherapy or psychotropic medication. Dropout analysis: no significant differences between completers and non-completers on baseline demographics or symptoms. Completion rates: T2=77.7% (160/206), T3=62.1% (128/206).
study_details.duration: 15 days of active intervention (3 levels/day, ~3 minutes daily, 45 total levels). Assessments at three timepoints: T1 (baseline), T2 (Day 15, post-intervention including resilience task), T3 (Day 45, 1-month follow-up). Total study duration approximately 45 days (6.5 weeks).
study_details.target_population: Heterosexual couples in committed relationships (≥1 year duration). Community sample without clinical diagnosis requirements - study targeted subclinical to clinical range ROCD symptoms. Adults aged 18-51 years. Both partners must have smartphones and Hebrew language proficiency. Not currently in psychotherapy or taking psychotropic medication.

study_content.summary: This groundbreaking RCT is the first to examine concurrent mobile health app use by both romantic partners for relationship OCD symptoms. The study evaluated the GGRO app's ability to promote resilience to ROCD symptoms during stressful periods. A unique feature was the 'resilience task' - exposure to a bogus triggering article designed to elicit ROCD doubts, administered at post-intervention to test whether app training provided protection against symptom increases. The app uses gamified CBT mechanics where users physically reject ROCD-related doubts (upward swipe) and embrace adaptive relationship beliefs (downward swipe). Content spans 5 thematic categories addressing relationship doubts, trust issues, self-acceptance, relationship building, and attachment security. Results demonstrated that while both groups showed improvements on self-reported ROCD measures over time, the critical finding emerged in the resilience task: control group participants experienced significant increases in ROCD symptoms when exposed to triggering content, while experimental group participants who used the app showed resilience (no symptom increase). This suggests the app may provide protective effects during relationship stressors rather than simply reducing baseline symptoms.
key_findings: Resilience task primary finding: Experimental group showed protection against ROCD symptom increase that occurred in control group. Control group post-trigger ROCD M=4.23 vs experimental group M=3.29, F(1,101)=14.89, p<.001, ηp²=0.13
Main treatment effects: Significant Time main effect for ROCI (relationship-centered ROCD): F(2,200)=3.86, p=.023, ηp²=0.04. Reduction from T1 to T3
PROCSI (partner-focused ROCD): Significant Time effect F(2,200)=4.39, p=.014, ηp²=0.04. Both groups showed symptom reduction over time
Relationship Catastrophizing (ReCats): Significant Group × Time interaction approaching significance F(2,200)=2.89, p=.058, ηp²=0.03. Experimental group showed greater reduction
OCD beliefs (OBQ-20): Significant Time effect F(2,200)=5.98, p=.003, ηp²=0.06. General reduction in maladaptive beliefs
Relationship satisfaction (RAS): Significant Time effect F(2,200)=4.12, p=.018, ηp²=0.04. Increased satisfaction for both groups
No significant Time × Group interactions for primary ROCD measures (ROCI, PROCSI), suggesting comparable self-reported improvement
Critical resilience finding: App use protected against symptom increase when faced with relationship-threatening information, even when baseline symptom changes were similar between groups
Gender effects: No significant Gender or Gender × Group × Time interactions, suggesting app equally effective for male and female partners
Dropout rate 22.33% (23/103 couples), with no baseline differences between completers and non-completers
Per-protocol analyses confirmed intention-to-treat findings, supporting robustness of results
Novel contribution: First study demonstrating dyadic mHealth intervention where both partners use app concurrently
Mechanism implications: Results suggest app builds resilience/protective factors rather than only reducing symptoms
Secondary outcomes: No significant changes in attachment anxiety/avoidance (ECR-S), sexual satisfaction (CSFQ-14), general distress (DASS-21), or social anxiety (SIAS)
study_content.results: Primary outcome analysis revealed the critical finding on the resilience task: after exposure to triggering content, control group participants showed elevated ROCD symptoms (M=4.23) while experimental group participants maintained lower ROCD symptoms (M=3.29), representing a large between-group difference (F(1,101)=14.89, p<.001, ηp²=0.13). This demonstrates that app use provided protection against symptom increases during relationship stress. For traditional pre-post measures, mixed MANOVAs showed significant Time main effects for both relationship-centered ROCD (ROCI: F(2,200)=3.86, p=.023, ηp²=0.04) and partner-focused ROCD (PROCSI: F(2,200)=4.39, p=.014, ηp²=0.04), with both groups showing symptom reduction from baseline to 1-month follow-up. However, Time × Group interactions were not significant for these primary measures, indicating comparable self-reported improvement between groups. Relationship Catastrophizing showed a trend toward Group × Time interaction (F(2,200)=2.89, p=.058, ηp²=0.03) favoring the experimental group. OCD beliefs (OBQ-20) decreased across time (F(2,200)=5.98, p=.003, ηp²=0.06) and relationship satisfaction increased (F(2,200)=4.12, p=.018, ηp²=0.04) for both groups. No significant effects emerged for attachment dimensions, sexual satisfaction, general distress, or social anxiety. Gender analyses revealed no significant differences, indicating both male and female partners benefited equally. Intention-to-treat analysis using MICE for missing data was confirmed by per-protocol sensitivity analyses. The pattern of results suggests the app's primary benefit may be building resilience to ROCD-triggering situations rather than simply reducing baseline symptoms.
study_content.statistical_significance: Resilience task: F(1,101)=14.89, p<.001, ηp²=0.13 (large effect, experimental group M=3.29 vs control M=4.23). ROCI Time effect: F(2,200)=3.86, p=.023, ηp²=0.04 (small effect). PROCSI Time effect: F(2,200)=4.39, p=.014, ηp²=0.04 (small effect). ReCats Group × Time interaction trend: F(2,200)=2.89, p=.058, ηp²=0.03 (marginal, small effect). OBQ-20 Time effect: F(2,200)=5.98, p=.003, ηp²=0.06 (small-medium effect). RAS Time effect: F(2,200)=4.12, p=.018, ηp²=0.04 (small effect). No significant Time × Group interactions for primary ROCD measures (ROCI and PROCSI). No significant Gender effects or Gender × Group × Time three-way interactions (all p>.05). All analyses used Bonferroni corrections for multiple comparisons. Intention-to-treat analyses with MICE imputation for missing data (22.33% dropout rate). Per-protocol sensitivity analyses confirmed primary findings. Alpha level set at p<.05 for all tests.
